books.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 1

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 1:1
verses.text: Refutation of All Heresies Book : Recapitulation; Characteristics of Heresy; Origin of the Name Naasseni; The System of the Naasseni.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 1:2
verses.text: I think that in the four preceding books I have very elaborately explained the opinions propounded by all the speculators among both Greeks and Barbarians, respecting the Divine Nature and the creation of the world; and not even have I omitted the consideration of their systems of magic.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 1:3
verses.text: So that I have for my readers undergone no ordinary amount of toil, in my anxiety to urge many forward into a desire of learning, and into stedfastness of knowledge in regard of the truth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 1:4
verses.text: It remains, therefore, to hasten on to the refutation of the heresies; but it is for the purpose of furnishing this (refutation) that we have put forward the statements already made by us.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 1:5
verses.text: For from philosophers the heresiarchs deriving starting-points, (and) like cobblers patching together, according to their own particular interpretation, the blunders of the ancients, have advanced them as novelties to those that are capable of being deceived, as we shall prove in the following books.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 1:6
verses.text: In the remainder (of our work), the opportunity invites us to approach the treatment of our proposed subjects, and to begin from those who have presumed to celebrate a serpent, the originator of the error (in question), through certain expressions devised by the energy of his own (ingenuity).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 1:7
verses.text: The priests, then, and champions of the system, have been first those who have been called Naasseni, being so denominated from the Hebrew language, for the serpent is called naas (in Hebrew).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 1:8
verses.text: Subsequently, however, they have styled themselves Gnostics, alleging that they alone have sounded the depths of knowledge.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 1:9
verses.text: Now, from the system of these (speculators), many, detaching parts, have constructed a heresy which, though with several subdivisions, is essentially one, and they explain precisely the same (tenets); though conveyed under the guise of different opinions, as the following discussion, according as it progresses, will prove.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 1:10
verses.text: These (Naasseni), then, according to the system advanced by them, magnify, (as the originating cause) of all things else, a man and a son of man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 1:11
verses.text: And this man is a hermaphrodite, and is denominated among them Adam; and hymns many and various are made to him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 1:12
verses.text: The hymns however—to be brief—are couched among them in some such form as this: "From thee (comes) father, and through thee (comes) mother, two names immortal, progenitors of aeons, O denizen of heaven, thou illustrious man".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 1:13
verses.text: But they divide him as Geryon into three parts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 1:14
verses.text: For, say they, of this man one part is rational, another psychical, another earthly.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 1:15
verses.text: And they suppose that the knowledge of him is the originating principle of the capacity for a knowledge of God, expressing themselves thus: "The originating principle of perfection is the knowledge of man, while the knowledge of God is absolute perfection".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 1:16
verses.text: All these qualities, however—rational, and psychical, and earthly—have, (the Naassene) says, retired and descended into one man simultaneously—Jesus, who was born of Mary.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 1:17
verses.text: And these three men (the Naassene) says, are in the habit of speaking (through Jesus) at the same time together, each from their own proper substances to those peculiarly their own.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 1:18
verses.text: For, according to these, there are three kinds of all existent things—angelic, psychical, earthly; and there are three churches—angelic, psychical, earthly; and the names of these are elect, called, captive.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:1
verses.text: Naasseni Ascribe Their System, Through Mariamne, to James the Lord's Brother; Really Traceable to the Ancient Mysteries; Their Psychology as Given in the "Gospel According to Thomas;" Assyrian Theory of the Soul; The Systems of the Naasseni and the Assyrians Compared; Support Drawn by the Naasseni from the Phrygian and Egyptian Mysteries; The Mysteries of Isis; These Mysteries Allegorized by the Naasseni.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:2
verses.text: These are the heads of very numerous discourses which (the Naassene) asserts James the brother of the Lord handed down to Mariamne.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:3
verses.text: In order, then, that these impious (heretics) may no longer belie Mariamne or James, or the Saviour Himself, let us come to the mystic rites (whence these have derived their figment),—to a consideration, if it seems right, of both the Barbarian and Grecian (mysteries),—and let us see how these (heretics), collecting together the secret and ineffable mysteries of all the Gentiles, are uttering falsehoods against Christ, and are making dupes of those who are not acquainted with these orgies of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:4
verses.text: For since the foundation of the doctrine with them is the man Adam, and they say that concerning him it has been written, "Who shall declare his generation?" learn how, partly deriving from the Gentiles the undiscoverable and diversified generation of the man, they fictitiously apply it to Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:5
verses.text: "Now earth," say the Greeks, "gave forth a man, (earth) first bearing a goodly gift, wishing to become mother not of plants devoid of sense, nor beasts without reason, but of a gentle and highly favoured creature".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:6
verses.text: "It, however, is difficult," (the Naassene) says, "to ascertain whether Alalcomeneus, first of men, rose upon the Boeotians over Lake Cephisus; or whether it were the Idaean Curetes, a divine race; or the Phrygian Corybantes, whom first the sun beheld springing up after the manner of the growth of trees; or whether Arcadia brought forth Pelasgus, of greater antiquity than the moon; or Eleusis (produced) Diaulus, an inhabitant of Raria; or Lemnus begot Cabirus, fair child of secret orgies; or Pallene (brought forth) the Phlegraean Alcyoneus, oldest of the giants.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:7
verses.text: But the Libyans affirm that Iarbas, first born, on emerging from arid plains, commenced eating the sweet acorn of Jupiter.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:8
verses.text: But the Nile of the Egyptians," he says, "up to this day fertilizing mud, (and therefore) generating animals, renders up living bodies, which acquire flesh from moist vapour".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:9
verses.text: The Assyrians, however, say that fish-eating Oannes was (the first man, and) produced among themselves.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:10
verses.text: The Chaldeans, however, say that this Adam is the man whom alone earth brought forth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:11
verses.text: And that he lay inanimate, unmoved, (and) still as a statue; being an image of him who is above, who is celebrated as the man Adam, having been begotten by many powers, concerning whom individually is an enlarged discussion.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:12
verses.text: In order, therefore, that finally the Great Man from above may be overpowered, "from whom," as they say, "the whole family named on earth and in the heavens has been formed, to him was given also a soul, that through the soul he might suffer; and that the enslaved image may be punished of the Great and most Glorious and Perfect Man, for even so they call him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:13
verses.text: Again, then, they ask what is the soul, and whence, and what kind in its nature, that, coming to the man and moving him, it should enslave and punish the image of the Perfect Man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:14
verses.text: They do not, however, (on this point) institute an inquiry from the Scriptures, but ask this (question) also from the mystic (rites).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:15
verses.text: And they affirm that the soul is very difficult to discover, and hard to understand; for it does not remain in the same figure or the same form invariably, or in one passive condition, that either one could express it by a sign, or comprehend it substantially.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:16
verses.text: But they have these varied changes (of the soul) set down in the gospel inscribed "according to the Egyptians".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:17
verses.text: They are, then, in doubt, as all the rest of men among the Gentiles, whether (the soul) is at all from something pre-existent, or whether from the self-produced (one), or from a widespread Chaos.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:18
verses.text: And first they fly for refuge to the mysteries of the Assyrians, perceiving the threefold division of the man; for the Assyrians first advanced the opinion that the soul has three parts, and yet (is essentially) one.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:19
verses.text: For of soul, say they, is every nature desirous, and each in a different manner.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:20
verses.text: For soul is cause of all things made; all things that are nourished, (the Naassene) says, and that grow, require soul.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:21
verses.text: For it is not possible, he says, to obtain any nourishment or growth where soul is not present.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:22
verses.text: For even stones, he affirms, are animated, for they possess what is capable of increase; but increase would not at any time take place without nourishment, for it is by accession that things which are being increased grow, but accession is the nourishment of things that are nurtured.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:23
verses.text: Every nature, then, (the Naasene) says, of things celestial, and earthly, and infernal, desires a soul.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:24
verses.text: And an entity of this description the Assyrians call Adonis or Endymion; and when it is styled Adonis, Venus, he says, loves and desires the soul when styled by such a name.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:25
verses.text: But Venus is production, according to them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:26
verses.text: But whenever Proserpine or Cora becomes enamoured with Adonis, there results, he says, a certain mortal soul separated from Venus (that is, from generation).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:27
verses.text: But should the Moon pass into concupiscence for Endymion, and into love of her form, the nature, he says, of the higher beings requires a soul likewise.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:28
verses.text: But if, he says, the mother of the gods emasculate Attis, and herself has this (person) as an object of affection, the blessed nature, he says, of the supernal and everlasting (beings) alone recalls the male power of the soul to itself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:29
verses.text: For (the Naassene) says, there is the hermaphrodite man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:30
verses.text: According to this account of theirs, the intercourse of woman with man is demonstrated, in conformity with such teaching, to be an exceedingly wicked and filthy (practice).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:31
verses.text: For, says (the Naassene), Attis has been emasculated, that is, he has passed over from the earthly parts of the nether world to the everlasting substance above, where, he says, there is neither female or male, but a new creature, a new man, which is hermaphrodite.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:32
verses.text: As to where, however, they use the expression "above," I shall show when I come to the proper place (for treating this subject).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:33
verses.text: But they assert that, by their account, they testify that Rhea is not absolutely isolated, but—for so I may say—the universal creature; and this they declare to be what is affirmed by the Word.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:34
verses.text: "For the invisible things of Him are seen from the creation of the world, being understood by the things that are made by Him, even His eternal power and Godhead, for the purpose of leaving them without excuse.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:35
verses.text: Wherefore, knowing God, they glorified Him not as God, nor gave Him thanks; but their foolish heart was rendered vain.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:36
verses.text: For, professing themselves to be wise, they became fools, and changed the glory of the uncorruptible God into images of the likeness of corruptible man, and of birds, and four-footed beasts, and creeping things.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:37
verses.text: Wherefore also God gave them up unto vile affections; for even their women did change the natural use into that which is against nature".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:38
verses.text: What, however, the natural use is, according to them, we shall afterwards declare.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:39
verses.text: "And likewise also the men, leaving the natural use of the woman, burned in their lust one toward another; men with men working that which is unseemly"—now the expression that which is unseemly signifies, according to these (Naasseni), the first and blessed substance, figureless, the cause of all figures to those things that are moulded into shapes,—"and receiving in themselves that recompense of their error which was meet".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:40
verses.text: For in these words which Paul has spoken they say the entire secret of theirs, and a hidden mystery of blessed pleasure, are comprised.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:41
verses.text: For the promise of washing is not any other, according to them, than the introduction of him that is washed in, according to them, life-giving water, and anointed with ineffable ointment (than his introduction) into unfading bliss.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:42
verses.text: But they assert that not only is there in favour of their doctrine, testimony to be drawn from the mysteries of the Assyrians, but also from those of the Phrygians concerning the happy nature—concealed, and yet at the same time disclosed—of things that have been, and are coming into existence, and moreover will be,—(a happy nature) which, (the Naassene) says, is the kingdom of heaven to be sought for within a man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:43
verses.text: And concerning this (nature) they hand down an explicit passage, occurring in the Gospel inscribed according to Thomas, expressing themselves thus: "He who seeks me, will find me in children from seven years old; for there concealed, I shall in the fourteenth age be made manifest".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:44
verses.text: This, however, is not (the teaching) of Christ, but of Hippocrates, who uses these words: "A child of seven years is half of a father".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:45
verses.text: And so it is that these (heretics), placing the originative nature of the universe in causative seed, (and) having ascertained the (aphorism) of Hippocrates, that a child of seven years old is half of a father, say that in fourteen years, according to Thomas, he is manifested.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:46
verses.text: This, with them, is the ineffable and mystical Logos.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:47
verses.text: They assert, then, that the Egyptians, who after the Phrygians, it is established, are of greater antiquity than all mankind, and who confessedly were the first to proclaim to all the rest of men the rites and orgies of, at the same time, all the gods, as well as the species and energies (of things), have the sacred and august, and for those who are not initiated, unspeakable mysteries of Isis.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:48
verses.text: These, however, are not anything else than what by her of the seven dresses and sable robe was sought and snatched away, namely, the pudendum of Osiris.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:49
verses.text: And they say that Osiris is water.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:50
verses.text: But the seven-robed nature, encircled and arrayed with seven mantles of ethereal texture—for so they call the planetary stars, allegorizing and denominating them ethereal robes,—is as it were the changeable generation, and is exhibited as the creature transformed by the ineffable and unportrayable, and inconceivable and figureless one.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:51
verses.text: And this, (the Naassene) says, is what is declared in Scripture, "The just will fall seven times, and rise again".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:52
verses.text: For these falls, he says, are the changes of the stars, moved by Him who puts all things in motion.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:53
verses.text: They affirm, then, concerning the substance of the seed which is a cause of all existent things, that it is none of these, but that it produces and forms all things that are made, expressing themselves thus: "I become what I wish, and I am what I am: on account of this I say, that what puts all things in motion is itself unmoved.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:54
verses.text: For what exists remains forming all things, and nought of existing things is made".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:55
verses.text: He says that this (one) alone is good, and that what is spoken by the Saviour is declared concerning this (one): "Why do you say that am good? One is good, my Father which is in the heavens, who causeth His sun to rise upon the just and unjust, and sendeth rain upon saints and sinners".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:56
verses.text: But who the saintly ones are on whom He sends the rain, and the sinners on whom the same sends the rain, this likewise we shall afterwards declare with the rest.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:57
verses.text: And this is the great and secret and unknown mystery of the universe, concealed and revealed among the Egyptians.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:58
verses.text: For Osiris, (the Naassene) says, is in temples in front of Isis; and his pudendum stands exposed, looking downwards, and crowned with all its own fruits of things that are made.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:59
verses.text: And (he affirms) that such stands not only in the most hallowed temples chief of idols, but that also, for the information of all, it is as it were a light not set under a bushel, but upon a candlestick, proclaiming its message upon the housetops, in all byways, and all streets, and near the actual dwellings, placed in front as a certain appointed limit and termination of the dwelling, and that this is denominated the good (entity) by all.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:60
verses.text: For they style this good-producing, not knowing what they say.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:61
verses.text: And the Greeks, deriving this mystical (expression) from the Egyptians, preserve it until this day.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:62
verses.text: For we behold, says (the Naassene), statues of Mercury, of such a figure honoured among them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:63
verses.text: Worshipping, however, Cyllenius with especial distinction, they style him Logios.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:64
verses.text: For Mercury is Logos, who being interpreter and fabricator of the things that have been made simultaneously, and that are being produced, and that will exist, stands honoured among them, fashioned into some such figure as is the pudendum of a man, having an impulsive power from the parts below towards those above.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:65
verses.text: And that this (deity)—that is, a Mercury of this description—is, (the Naassene) says, a conjurer of the dead, and a guide of departed spirits, and an originator of souls; nor does this escape the notice of the poets, who express themselves thus:—  "Cyllenian Hermes also called  The souls of mortal suitors".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:66
verses.text: Not Penelope's suitors, says he, O wretches! but (souls) awakened and brought to recollection of themselves,  "From honour so great, and from bliss so long".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:67
verses.text: That is, from the blessed man from above, or the primal man or Adam, as it seems to them, souls have been conveyed down here into a creation of clay, that they may serve the Demiurge of this creation, Ialdabaoth, a fiery God, a fourth number; for so they call the Demiurge and father of the formal world:—  "And in hand he held a lovely  Wand of gold that human eyes enchants,  Of whom he will, and those again who slumber rouses".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:68
verses.text: This, he says, is he who alone has power of life and death.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:69
verses.text: Concerning this, he says, it has been written, "Thou shalt rule them with a rod of iron".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:70
verses.text: The poet, however, he says, being desirous of adorning the incomprehensible (potency) of the blessed nature of the Logos, invested him with not an iron, but golden wand.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:71
verses.text: And he enchants the eyes of the dead, as he says, and raises up again those that are slumbering, after having been roused from sleep, and after having been suitors.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:72
verses.text: And concerning these, he says, the Scripture speaks: "Awake thou that sleepest, and arise, and Christ will give thee light".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:73
verses.text: This is the Christ who, he says, in all that have been generated, is the portrayed Son of Man from the unportrayable Logos.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:74
verses.text: This, he says, is the great and unspeakable mystery of the Eleusinian rites, Hye, Cye.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:75
verses.text: And he affirms that all things have been subjected unto him, and this is that which has been spoken, "Their sound is gone forth unto all the earth," just as it agrees with the expressions, "Mercury waving his wand, guides the souls, but they twittering follow".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:76
verses.text: I mean the disembodied spirits follow continuously in such a way as the poet by his imagery delineates, using these words:—  "And as when in the magic cave's recess  Bats humming fly, and when one drops  From ridge of rock, and each to other closely clings".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:77
verses.text: The expression "rock," he says, he uses of Adam.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:78
verses.text: This, he affirms, is Adam: "The chief corner-stone become the head of the corner".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:79
verses.text: For that in the head the substance is the formative brain from which the entire family is fashioned.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:80
verses.text: "Whom," he says, "I place as a rock at the foundations of Zion".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:81
verses.text: Allegorizing, he says, he speaks of the creation of the man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:82
verses.text: The rock is interposed (within) the teeth, as Homer says, "enclosure of teeth," that is, a wall and fortress, in which exists the inner man, who thither has fallen from Adam, the primal man above.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:83
verses.text: And he has been "severed without hands to effect the division," and has been borne down into the image of oblivion, being earthly and clayish.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:84
verses.text: And he asserts that the twittering spirits follow him, that is, the Logos:—  "Thus these, twittering, came together; and then the souls  That is, he guides them;  Gentle Hermes led through wide-extended paths".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:85
verses.text: That is, he says, into the eternal places separated from all wickedness.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:86
verses.text: For whither, he says, did they come:—  "O'er ocean's streams they came, and Leuca's cliff,  And by the portals of the sun and land of dreams".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:87
verses.text: This, he says, is ocean, "generation of gods and generation of men" ever whirled round by the eddies of water, at one time upwards, at another time downwards.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:88
verses.text: But he says there ensues a generation of men when the ocean flows downwards; but when upwards to the wall and fortress and the cliff of Luecas, a generation of gods takes place.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:89
verses.text: This, he asserts, is that which has been written: "I said, Ye are gods, and all children of the highest;" "If ye hasten to fly out of Egypt, and repair beyond the Red Sea into the wilderness," that is, from earthly intercourse to the Jerusalem above, which is the mother of the living; "If, moreover, again you return into Egypt," that is, into earthly intercourse, "ye shall die as men".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:90
verses.text: For mortal, he says, is every generation below, but immortal that which is begotten above, for it is born of water only, and of spirit, being spiritual, not carnal.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:91
verses.text: But what (is born) below is carnal, that is, he says, what is written.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:92
verses.text: "That which is born of the flesh is flesh, and that which is born of the spirit is spirit".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:93
verses.text: This, according to them, is the spiritual generation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 2:94
verses.text: This, he says, is the great Jordan which, flowing on (here) below, and preventing the children of Israel from departing out of Egypt—I mean from terrestrial intercourse, for Egypt is with them the body,—Jesus drove back, and made it flow upwards.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:1
verses.text: Further Exposition of the Heresy of the Naasseni; Profess to Follow Homer; Acknowledge a Triad of Principles; Their Technical Names of the Triad; Support These on the Authority of Greek Poets; Allegorize Our Saviour's Miracles; The Mystery of the Samothracians; Why the Lord Chose Twelve Disciples; The Name Corybas, Used by Thracians and Phrygians, Explained; Naasseni Profess to Find Their System in Scripture; Their Interpretation of Jacob's Vision; Their Idea of the "Perfect Man;" The "Perfect Man" Called "Papa" By the Phrygians; The Naasseni and Phrygians on the Resurrection; The Ecstasis of St.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:2
verses.text: Paul; The Mysteries of Religion as Alluded to by Christ; Interpretation of the Parable of the Sower; Allegory of the Promised Land; Comparison of the System of the Phrygians with the Statements of Scripture; Exposition of the Meaning of the Higher and Lower Eleusinian Mysteries; The Incarnation Discoverable Here According to the Naasseni.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:3
verses.text: Adopting these and such like (opinions), these most marvellous Gnostics, inventors of a novel grammatical art, magnify Homer as their prophet—as one, (according to them,) who, after the mode adopted in the mysteries, announces these truths; and they mock those who are not indoctrinated into the holy Scriptures, by betraying them into such notions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:4
verses.text: They make, however, the following assertion: he who says that all things derive consistence from one, is in error; but he who says that they are of three, is in possession of the truth, and will furnish a solution of the (phenomena of the) universe.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:5
verses.text: For there is, says (the Naassene), one blessed nature of the Blessed Man, of him who is above, (namely) Adam; and there is one mortal nature, that which is below; and there is one kingless generation, which is begotten above, where, he says, is Mariam the sought-for one, and Iothor the mighty sage, and Sephora the gazing one, and Moses whose generation is not in Egypt, for children were born unto him in Madian; and not even this, he says, has escaped the notice of the poets.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:6
verses.text: "Threefold was our partition; each obtained  His meed of honour due".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:7
verses.text: For, says he, it is necessary that the magnitudes be declared, and that they thus be declared by all everywhere, "in order that hearing they may not hear, and seeing they may not see".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:8
verses.text: For if, he says, the magnitudes were not declared, the world could not have obtained consistence.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:9
verses.text: These are the three tumid expressions (of these heretics), Caulacau, Saulasau, Zeesar, i-e:, Adam, who is farthest above; Saulasau, that is, the mortal one below; Zeesar, that is, Jordan that flows upwards.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:10
verses.text: This, he says, is the hermaphrodite man (present) in all.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:11
verses.text: But those who are ignorant of him, call him Geryon with the threefold body—Geryon, i-e:, as if (in the sense of) flowing from earth—but (whom) the Greeks by common consent (style) "celestial horn of the moon," because he mixed and blended all things in all.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:12
verses.text: "For all things," he says, "were made by him, and not even one thing was made without him, and what was made in him is life".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:13
verses.text: This, says he, is the life, the ineffable generation of perfect men, which was not known by preceding generations.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:14
verses.text: But the passage, "nothing was made without him," refers to the formal world, for it was created without his instrumentality by the third and fourth (of the quaternion named above).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:15
verses.text: For says he, this is the cup "Condy, out of which the king, while he quaffs, draws his omens".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:16
verses.text: This, he says, has been discovered hid in the beauteous seeds of Benjamin.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:17
verses.text: And the Greeks likewise, he says, speak of this in the following terms:—  "Water to the raging mouth bring; thou slave, bring wine;  Intoxicate and plunge me into stupor.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:18
verses.text: My tankard tells me  The sort I must become".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:19
verses.text: This, says he, was alone sufficient for its being understood by men; (I mean) the cup of Anacreon declaring, (albeit) mutely, an ineffable mystery.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:20
verses.text: For dumb, says he, is Anacreon's cup; and (yet) Anacreon affirms that it speaks to himself, in language mute, as to what sort he must become—that is spiritual, not carnal—if he shall listen in silence to the concealed mystery.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:21
verses.text: And this is the water in those fair nuptials which Jesus changing made into wine.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:22
verses.text: This, he says, is the mighty and true beginning of miracles which Jesus performed in Cana of Galilee, and (thus) manifested the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:23
verses.text: This, says he, is the kingdom of heaven that reposes within us as a treasure, as leaven hid in the three measures of meal.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:24
verses.text: This is, he says, the great and ineffable mystery of the Samothracians, which it is allowable, he says, for us only who are initiated to know.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:25
verses.text: For the Samothracians expressly hand down, in the mysteries that are celebrated among them, that (same) Adam as the primal man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:26
verses.text: And habitually there stand in the temple of the Samothracians two images of naked men, having both hands stretched aloft towards heaven, and their pudenda erecta, as with the statue of Mercury on Mount Cyllene.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:27
verses.text: And the aforesaid images are figures of the primal man, and of that spiritual one that is born again, in every respect of the same substance with that man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:28
verses.text: This, he says, is what is spoken by the Saviour: "If ye do not drink my blood, and eat my flesh, ye will not enter into the kingdom of heaven; but even though," He says, "ye drink of the cup which I drink of, whither I go, ye cannot enter there".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:29
verses.text: For He says He was aware of what sort of nature each of His disciples was, and that there was a necessity that each of them should attain unto His own peculiar nature.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:30
verses.text: For He says He chose twelve disciples from the twelve tribes, and spoke by them to each tribe.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:31
verses.text: On this account, He says, the preachings of the twelve disciples neither did all hear, nor, if they heard, could they receive.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:32
verses.text: For the things that are not according to nature, are with them contrary to nature.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:33
verses.text: This, he says, the Thracians who dwell around Haemus, and the Phrygians similarly with the Thracians, denominate Corybas, because, (though) deriving the beginning of his descent from the head above and from the unportrayed brain, and (though) permeating all the principles of the existing state of things, (yet) we do not perceive how and in what manner he comes down.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:34
verses.text: This, says he, is what is spoken: "We have heard his voice, no doubt, but we have not seen his shape".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:35
verses.text: For the voice of him that is set apart and portrayed is heard; but (his) shape, which descends from above from the unportrayed one,—what sort it is, nobody knows.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:36
verses.text: It resides, however, in an earthly mould, yet no one recognises it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:37
verses.text: This, he says, is "the god that inhabiteth the flood," according to the Psalter, "and who speaketh and crieth from many waters".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:38
verses.text: The "many waters," he says, are the diversified generation of mortal men, from which (generation) he cries and vociferates to the unportrayed man, saying, "Preserve my only-begotten from the lions".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:39
verses.text: In reply to him, it has, says he, been declared, "Israel, thou art my child: fear not; even though thou passest through rivers, they shall not drown thee; even though thou passest through fire, it shall not scorch thee".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:40
verses.text: By rivers he means, says he, the moist substance of generation, and by fire the impulsive principle and desire for generation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:41
verses.text: "Thou art mine; fear not".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:42
verses.text: And again, he says, "If a mother forget her children, so as not to have pity on them and give them food, I also will forget you".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:43
verses.text: Adam, he says, speaks to his own men: "But even though a woman forget these things, yet I will not forget you.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:44
verses.text: I have painted you on my hands".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:45
verses.text: In regard, however, of his ascension, that is his regeneration, that he may become spiritual, not carnal, the Scripture, he says, speaks (thus): "Open the gates, ye who are your rulers; and be ye lift up, ye everlasting doors, and the King of glory shall come in," that is a wonder of wonders.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:46
verses.text: "For who," he says, "is this King of glory? A worm, and not a man; a reproach of man, and an outcast of the people; himself is the King of glory, and powerful in war".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:47
verses.text: And by war he means the war that is in the body, because its frame has been made out of hostile elements; as it has been written, he says, "Remember the conflict that exists in the body".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:48
verses.text: Jacob, he says, saw this entrance and this gate in his journey into Mesopotamia, that is, when from a child he was now becoming a youth and a man; that is, (the entrance and gate) were made known unto him as he journeyed into Mesopotamia.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:49
verses.text: But Mesopotamia, he says, is the current of the great ocean flowing from the midst of the Perfect Man; and he was astonished at the celestial gate, exclaiming, "How terrible is this place! it is nought else than the house of God, and this (is) the gate of heaven".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:50
verses.text: On account of this, he says, Jesus uses the words, "I am the true gate".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:51
verses.text: Now he who makes these statements is, he says, the Perfect Man that is imaged from the unportrayable one from above.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:52
verses.text: The Perfect Man therefore cannot, he says, be saved, unless, entering in through this gate, he be born again.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:53
verses.text: But this very one the Phrygians, he says, call also Papa, because he tranquillized all things which, prior to his manifestation, were confusedly and dissonantly moved.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:54
verses.text: For the name, he says, of Papa belongs simultaneously to all creatures—celestial, and terrestrial, and infernal—who exclaim, Cause to cease, cause to cease the discord of the world, and make "peace for those that are afar off," that is, for material and earthly beings; and "peace for those that are near," that is, for perfect men that are spiritual and endued with reason.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:55
verses.text: But the Phrygians denominate this same also "corpse"—buried in the body, as it were, in a mausoleum and tomb.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:56
verses.text: This, he says, is what has been declared, "Ye are whited sepulchres, full," he says, "of dead men's bones within," because there is not in you the living man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:57
verses.text: And again he exclaims, "The dead shall start forth from the graves," that is, from the earthly bodies, being born again spiritual, not carnal.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:58
verses.text: For this, he says, is the Resurrection that takes place through the gate of heaven, through which, he says, all those that do not enter remain dead.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:59
verses.text: These same Phrygians, however, he says, affirm again that this very (man), as a consequence of the change, (becomes) a god.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:60
verses.text: For, he says, he becomes a god when, having risen from the dead, he will enter into heaven through a gate of this kind.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:61
verses.text: Paul the apostle, he says, knew of this gate, partially opening it in a mystery, and stating "that he was caught up by an angel, and ascended as far as the second and third heaven into paradise itself; and that he beheld sights and heard unspeakable words which it would not be possible for man to declare".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:62
verses.text: These are, he says, what are by all called the secret mysteries, "which (also we speak), not in words taught of human wisdom, but in those taught of the Spirit, comparing spiritual things with spiritual.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:63
verses.text: But the natural man receiveth not the things of the Spirit of God, for they are foolishness unto him".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:64
verses.text: And these are, he says, the ineffable mysteries of the Spirit, which we alone are acquainted with.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:65
verses.text: Concerning these, he says, the Saviour has declared, "No one can come unto me, except my heavenly Father draw some one unto me".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:66
verses.text: For it is very difficult, he says, to accept and receive this great and ineffable mystery.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:67
verses.text: And again, it is said, the Saviour has declared, "Not every one that saith unto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of heaven, but he that doeth the will of my Father which is in heaven".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:68
verses.text: And it is necessary that they who perform this (will), not hear it merely, should enter into the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:69
verses.text: And again, he says, the Saviour has declared, "The publicans and the harlots go into the kingdom of heaven before you".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:70
verses.text: For "the publicans," he says, are those who receive the revenues of all things; but we, he says, are the publicans, "unto whom the ends of the ages have come".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:71
verses.text: For "the ends," he says, are the seeds scattered from the unportrayable one upon the world, through which the whole cosmical system is completed; for through these also it began to exist.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:72
verses.text: And this, he says, is what has been declared: "The sower went forth to sow.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:73
verses.text: And some fell by the wayside, and was trodden down; and some on the rocky places, and sprang up," he says, "and on account of its having no depth (of soil), it withered and died; and some," he says, "fell on fair and good ground, and brought forth fruit, some a hundred, some sixty, and some thirty fold.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:74
verses.text: Who hath ears," he says, "to hear, let him hear".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:75
verses.text: The meaning of this, he says, is as follows, that none becomes a hearer of these mysteries, unless only the perfect Gnostics.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:76
verses.text: This, he says, is the fair and good land which Moses speaks of: "I will bring you into a fair and good land, into a land flowing with milk and honey".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:77
verses.text: This, he says, is the honey and the milk, by tasting which those that are perfect become kingless, and share in the Pleroma.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:78
verses.text: This, he says, is the Pleroma, through which all existent things that are produced have from the ingenerable one been both produced and completed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:79
verses.text: And this same (one) is styled also by the Phrygians "unfruitful".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:80
verses.text: For he is unfruitful when he is carnal, and causes the desire of the flesh.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:81
verses.text: This, he says, is what is spoken: "Every tree not producing good fruit, is cut down and cast into the fire".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:82
verses.text: For these fruits, he says, are only rational living men, who enter in through the third gate.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:83
verses.text: They say, forsooth, "Ye devour the dead, and make the living; (but) if ye eat the living, what will ye do?" They assert, however, that the living "are rational faculties and minds, and men—pearls of that unportrayable one cast before the creature below".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:84
verses.text: This, he says, is what (Jesus) asserts: "Throw not that which is holy unto the dogs, nor pearls unto the swine".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:85
verses.text: Now they allege that the work of swine and dogs is the intercourse of the woman with a man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:86
verses.text: And the Phrygians, he says, call this very one "goat-herd" (Aipolis), not because, he says, he is accustomed to feed the goats female and male, as the natural (men) use the name, but because, he says, he is "Aipolis"—that is, always ranging over,—who both revolves and carries around the entire cosmical system by his revolutionary motion.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:87
verses.text: For the word "Polein" signifies to turn and change things; whence, he says, they all call the twos centre of the heaven poles (Poloi).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:88
verses.text: And the poet says:—  "What sea-born sinless sage comes hither,  Undying Egyptian Proteus?"  He is not undone, he says, but revolves as it were, and goes round himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:89
verses.text: Moreover, also, cities in which we dwell, because we turn and go round in them, are denominated "Poleis".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:90
verses.text: In this manner, he says, the Phrygians call this one "Aipolis," inasmuch as he everywhere ceaselessly turns all things, and changes them into their own peculiar (functions).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:91
verses.text: And the Phrygians style him, he says, "very fruitful" likewise, "because," says he, "more numerous are the children of the desolate one, than those of her which hath an husband;" that is, things by being born again become immortal and abide for ever in great numbers, even though the things that are produced may be few; whereas things carnal, he says, are all corruptible, even though very many things (of this type) are produced.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:92
verses.text: For this reason, he says, "Rachel wept for her children, and would not," says (the prophet), "be comforted; sorrowing for them, for she knew," says he, "that they are not".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:93
verses.text: But Jeremiah likewise utters lamentation for Jerusalem below, not the city in Phoenicia, but the corruptible generation below.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:94
verses.text: For Jeremiah likewise, he says, was aware of the Perfect Man, of him that is born again—of water and the Spirit not carnal.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:95
verses.text: At least Jeremiah himself remarked: "He is a man, and who shall know him?" In this manner, (the Naassene) says, the knowledge of the Perfect Man is exceedingly profound, and difficult of comprehension.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:96
verses.text: For, he says, the beginning of perfection is a knowledge of man, whereas knowledge of God is absolute perfection.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:97
verses.text: The Phrygians, however, assert, he says, that he is likewise "a green ear of corn reaped".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:98
verses.text: And after the Phrygians, the Athenians, while initiating people into the Eleusinian rites, likewise display to those who are being admitted to the highest grade at these mysteries, the mighty, and marvellous, and most perfect secret suitable for one initiated into the highest mystic truths: (I allude to) an ear of corn in silence reaped.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:99
verses.text: But this ear of corn is also (considered) among the Athenians to constitute the perfect enormous illumination (that has descended) from the unportrayable one, just as the Hierophant himself (declares); not, indeed, emasculated like Attis, but made a eunuch by means of hemlock, and despising all carnal generation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:100
verses.text: (Now) by night in Eleusis, beneath a huge fire, (the Celebrant) enacting the great and secret mysteries, vociferates and cries aloud, saying, "August Brimo has brought forth a consecrated son, Brimus;" that is, a potent (mother has been delivered of) a potent child.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:101
verses.text: But revered, he says, is the generation that is spiritual, heavenly, from above, and potent is he that is so born.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:102
verses.text: For the mystery is called "Eleusin" and "Anactorium".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:103
verses.text: "Eleusin," because, he says, we who are spiritual come flowing down from Adam above; for the word "eleusesthai" is, he says, of the same import with the expression "to come".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:104
verses.text: But "Anactorium" is of the same import with the expression "to ascend upwards".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:105
verses.text: This, he says, is what they affirm who have been initiated in the mysteries of the Eleusinians.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:106
verses.text: It is, however, a regulation of law, that those who have been admitted into the lesser should again be initiated into the Great Mysteries.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:107
verses.text: For greater destinies obtain greater portions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:108
verses.text: But the inferior mysteries, he says, are those of Proserpine below; in regard of which mysteries, and the path which leads thither, which is wide and spacious, and conducts those that are perishing to Proserpine, the poet likewise says:—  "But under her a fearful path extends,  Hollow, miry, yet best guide to  Highly-honoured Aphrodite's lovely grove".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:109
verses.text: These, he says, are the inferior mysteries, those appertaining to carnal generation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:110
verses.text: Now, those men who are initiated into these inferior (mysteries) ought to pause, and (then) be admitted into the great (and) heavenly (ones).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:111
verses.text: For they, he says, who obtain their shares (in this mystery), receive greater portions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:112
verses.text: For this, he says, is the gate of heaven; and this a house of God, where the Good Deity dwells alone.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:113
verses.text: And into this (gate), he says, no unclean person shall enter, nor one that is natural or carnal; but it is reserved for the spiritual only.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:114
verses.text: And those who come hither ought to cast off their garments, and become all of them bridegrooms, emasculated through the virginal spirit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:115
verses.text: For this is the virgin who carries in her womb and conceives and brings forth a son, not animal, not corporeal, but blessed for evermore.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 3:116
verses.text: Concerning these, it is said, the Saviour has expressly declared that "straight and narrow is the way that leadeth unto life, and few there are that enter upon it; whereas broad and spacious is the way that leadeth unto destruction, and many there are that pass through it".

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:1
verses.text: Further Use Made of the System of the Phrygians; Mode of Celebrating the Mysteries; The Mystery of the "Great Mother;" These Mysteries Have a Joint Object of Worship with the Naasseni; The Naasseni Allegorize the Scriptural Account of the Garden of Eden; The Allegory Applied to the Life of Jesus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:2
verses.text: The Phrygians, however, further assert that the father of the universe is "Amygdalus," not a tree, he says, but that he is "Amygdalus" who previously existed; and he having in himself the perfect fruit, as it were, throbbing and moving in the depth, rent his breasts, and produced his now invisible, and nameless, and ineffable child, respecting whom we shall speak.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:3
verses.text: For the word "Amyxai" signifies, as it were, to burst and sever through, as he says (happens) in the case of inflamed bodies, and which have in themselves any tumour; and when doctors have cut this, they call it "Amychai".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:4
verses.text: In this way, he says, the Phrygians call him "Amygdalus," from which proceeded and was born the Invisible (One), "by whom all things were made, and nothing was made without Him".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:5
verses.text: And the Phrygians say that what has been thence produced is "Syrictas" (piper), because the Spirit that is born is harmonious.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:6
verses.text: "For God," he says, "is Spirit; wherefore," he affirms, "neither in this mountain do the true worshippers worship, nor in Jerusalem, but in spirit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:7
verses.text: For the adoration of the perfect ones," he says, "is spiritual, not carnal".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:8
verses.text: The Spirit, however, he says, is there where likewise the Father is named, and the Son is there born from this Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:9
verses.text: This, he says, is the many-named, thousand-eyed Incomprehensible One, of whom every nature—each, however, differently—is desirous.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:10
verses.text: This, he says, is the word of God, which, he says, is a word of revelation of the Great Power.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:11
verses.text: Wherefore it will be sealed, and hid, and concealed, lying in the habitation where lies the basis of the root of the universe, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:12
verses.text: aeons, Powers, Intelligences, Gods, Angels, delegated Spirits, Entities, Nonentities, Generables, Ingenerables, Incomprehensibles, Comprehensibles, Years, Months, Days, Hours, (and) Invisible Point from which what is least begins to increase gradually.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:13
verses.text: That which is, he says, nothing, and which consists of nothing, inasmuch as it is indivisible—(I mean) a point—will become through its own reflective power a certain incomprehensible magnitude.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:14
verses.text: This, he says, is the kingdom of heaven, the grain of mustard seed, the point which is indivisible in the body; and, he says, no one knows this (point) save the spiritual only.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:15
verses.text: This, he says, is what has been spoken: "There is no speech nor language where their voice is not heard".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:16
verses.text: They rashly assume in this manner, that whatsoever things have been said and done by all men, (may be made to harmonize) with their own particular mental view, alleging that all things become spiritual.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:17
verses.text: Whence likewise they assert, that those exhibiting themselves in theatres,—not even these say or do anything without premeditation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:18
verses.text: Therefore, he says, when, on the people assembling in the theatres, any one enters clad in a remarkable robe, carrying a harp and playing a tune (upon it, accompanying it) with a song of the great mysteries, he speaks as follows, not knowing what he says: "Whether (thou art) the race of Saturn or happy Jupiter, or mighty Rhea, Hail, Attis, gloomy mutilation of Rhea.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:19
verses.text: Assyrians style thee thrice-longed-for Adonis, and the whole of Egypt (calls thee) Osiris, celestial horn of the moon; Greeks denominate (thee) Wisdom; Samothracians, venerable Adam; Haemonians, Corybas; and them Phrygians (name thee) at one time Papa, at another time Corpse, or God, or Fruitless, or Aipolos, or green Ear of Corn that has been reaped, or whom the very fertile Amygdalus produced—a man, a musician".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:20
verses.text: This, he says, is multiform Attis, whom while they celebrate in a hymn, they utter these words: "I will hymn Attis, son of Rhea, not with the buzzing sounds of trumpets, or of Idaean pipers, which accord with (the voices of) the Curetes; but I will mingle (my song) with Apollo's music of harps, 'evoe, evan,' inasmuch as thou art Pan, as thou art Bacchus, as thou art shepherd of brilliant stars".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:21
verses.text: On account of these and such like reasons, these constantly attend the mysteries called those of the "Great Mother," supposing especially that they behold by means of the ceremonies performed there the entire mystery.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:22
verses.text: For these have nothing more than the ceremonies that are performed there, except that they are not emasculated: they merely complete the work of the emasculated.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:23
verses.text: For with the utmost severity and vigilance they enjoin (on their votaries) to abstain, as if they were emasculated, from intercourse with a woman.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:24
verses.text: The rest, however, of the proceeding (observed in these mysteries), as we have declared at some length, (they follow) just as (if they were) emasculated persons.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:25
verses.text: And they do not worship any other object but Naas, (from thence) being styled Naasseni.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:26
verses.text: But Naas is the serpent from whom, i-e:, from the word Naas, (the Naassene) says, are all that under heaven are denominated temples (Naous).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:27
verses.text: And (he states) that to him alone—that is, Naas—is dedicated every shrine and every initiatory rite, and every mystery; and, in general, that a religious ceremony could not be discovered under heaven, in which a temple (Naos) has no existence; and in the temple itself is Naas, from whom it has received its denomination of temple (Naos).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:28
verses.text: And these affirm that the serpent is a moist substance, just as Thales also, the Milesian, (spoke of water as an originating principle,) and that nothing of existing things, immortal or mortal, animate or inanimate, could consist at all without him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:29
verses.text: And that all things are subject unto him, and that he is good, and that he has all things in himself, as in the horn of the one-horned bull; so as that he imparts beauty and bloom to all things that exist according to their own nature and peculiarity, as if passing through all, just as ("the river) proceeding forth from Edem, and dividing itself into four heads".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:30
verses.text: They assert, however, that Edem is the brain, as it were, bound and tightly fastened in encircling robes, as if (in) heaven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:31
verses.text: But they suppose that man, as far as the head only, is Paradise, therefore that "this river, which proceeds out of Edem," that is, from the brain, "is divided into four heads, and that the name of the first river is called Phison; this is that which encompasseth all the land of Havilath: there is gold, and the gold of that land is excellent, and there is bdellium and the onyx stone".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:32
verses.text: This, he says, is the eye, which, by its honour (among the rest of the bodily organs), and its colours, furnishes testimony to what is spoken.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:33
verses.text: "But the name of the second river is Gihon: this is that which compasseth the land of Ethiopia".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:34
verses.text: This, he says, is hearing, since Gihon is (a tortuous stream), resembling a sort of labyrinth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:35
verses.text: "And the name of the third is Tigris.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:36
verses.text: This is that which floweth over against (the country of) the Assyrians".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:37
verses.text: This, he says, is smelling, employing the exceedingly rapid current of the stream (as an analogy of this sense).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:38
verses.text: But it flows over against (the country of) the Assyrians, because in every act of respiration following upon expiration, the breath drawn in from the external atmosphere enters with swifter motion and greater force.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:39
verses.text: For this, he says, is the nature of respiration.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:40
verses.text: "But the fourth river is Euphrates".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:41
verses.text: This, they assert, is the mouth, through which are the passage outwards of prayer, and the passage inwards of nourishment.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:42
verses.text: (The mouth) makes glad, and nurtures and fashions the Spiritual Perfect Man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:43
verses.text: This, he says, is "the water that is above the firmament," concerning which, he says, the Saviour has declared, "If thou knewest who it is that asks, thou wouldst have asked from Him, and He would have given you to drink living, bubbling water".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:44
verses.text: Into this water, he says, every nature enters, choosing its own substances; and its peculiar quality comes to each nature from this water, he says, more than iron does to the magnet, and the gold to the backbone of the sea falcon, and the chaff to the amber.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:45
verses.text: But if any one, he says, is blind from birth, and has never beheld the true light, "which lighteneth every man that cometh into the world," by us let him recover his sight, and behold, as it were, through some paradise planted with every description of tree, and supplied with abundance of fruits, water coursing its way through all the trees and fruits; and he will see that from one and the same water the olive chooses for itself and draws the oil, and the vine the wine; and (so is it with) the rest of plants, according to each genus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:46
verses.text: That Man, however, he says, is of no reputation in the world, but of illustrious fame in heaven, being betrayed by those who are ignorant (of his perfections) to those who know him not, being accounted as a drop from a cask.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:47
verses.text: We, however, he says, are spiritual, who, from the life-giving water of Euphrates, which flows through the midst of Babylon, choose our own peculiar quality as we pass through the true gate, which is the blessed Jesus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 4:48
verses.text: And of all men, we Christians alone are those who in the third gate celebrate the mystery, and are anointed there with the unspeakable chrism from a horn, as David (was anointed), not from an earthen vessel, he says, as (was) Saul, who held converse with the evil demon of carnal concupiscence.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 5

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 5:1
verses.text: Explanation of the System of the Naasseni Taken from One of Their Hymns.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 5:2
verses.text: The foregoing remarks, then, though few out of many, we have thought proper to bring forward.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 5:3
verses.text: For innumerable are the silly and crazy attempts of folly.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 5:4
verses.text: But since, to the best of our ability, we have explained the unknown Gnosis, it seemed expedient likewise to adduce the following point.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 5:5
verses.text: This psalm of theirs has been composed, by which they seem to celebrate all the mysteries of the error (advanced by) them in a hymn, couched in the following terms:—  The world's producing law was Primal Mind,  And next was First-born's outpoured Chaos;  And third, the soul received its law of toil:  Encircl'd, therefore, with an aqueous form,  With care o'erpowered it succumbs to death.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 5:6
verses.text: Now holding sway, it eyes the light,  And now it weeps on misery flung;  Now it mourns, now it thrills with joy;  Now it wails, now it hears its doom;  Now it hears its doom, now it dies,  And now it leaves us, never to return.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 5:7
verses.text: It, hapless straying, treads the maze of ills.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 5:8
verses.text: But Jesus said, Father, behold,  A strife of ills across the earth  Wanders from thy breath (of wrath);  But bitter Chaos (man) seeks to shun,  And knows not how to pass it through.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 5:9
verses.text: On this account, O Father, send me;  Bearing seals, I shall descend;  Through ages whole I'll sweep,  All mysteries I'll unravel,  And forms of Gods I'll show;  And secrets of the saintly path,  Styled "Gnosis," I'll impart.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 6

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 6:1
verses.text: These doctrines, then, the Naasseni attempt to establish, calling themselves Gnostics.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 6:2
verses.text: But since the error is many-headed and diversified, resembling, in truth, the hydra that we read of in history; when, at one blow, we have struck off the heads of this (delusion) by means of refutation, employing the wand of truth, we shall entirely exterminate the monster.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 6:3
verses.text: For neither do the remaining heresies present much difference of aspect from this, having a mutual connection through (the same) spirit of error.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 6:4
verses.text: But since, altering the words and the names of the serpent, they wish that there should be many heads of the serpent, neither thus shall we fail thoroughly to refute them as they desire.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 7

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 7:1
verses.text: The System of the Peratae; Their Tritheism; Explanation of the Incarnation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 7:2
verses.text: There is also unquestionably a certain other (head of the hydra, namely, the heresy) of the Peratae, whose blasphemy against Christ has for many years escaped notice.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 7:3
verses.text: And the present is a fitting opportunity for bringing to light the secret mysteries of such (heretics).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 7:4
verses.text: These allege that the world is one, triply divided.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 7:5
verses.text: And of the triple division with them, one portion is a certain single originating principle, just as it were a huge fountain, which can be divided mentally into infinite segments.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 7:6
verses.text: Now the first segment, and that which, according to them, is (a segment) in preference (to others), is a triad, and it is called a Perfect Good, (and) a Paternal Magnitude.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 7:7
verses.text: And the second portion of the triad of these is, as it were, a certain infinite crowd of potentialities that are generated from themselves, (while) the third is formal.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 7:8
verses.text: And the first, which is good, is unbegotten, and the second is a self-producing good, and the third is created; and hence it is that they expressly declare that there are three Gods, three Logoi, three Minds, three Men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 7:9
verses.text: For to each portion of the world, after the division has been made, they assign both Gods, and Logoi, and Minds, and Men, and the rest; but that from unorigination and the first segment of the world, when afterwards the world had attained unto its completion, there came down from above, for causes that we shall afterwards declare, in the time of Herod a certain man called Christ, with a threefold nature, and a threefold body, and a threefold power, (and) having in himself all (species of) concretions and potentialities (derivable) from the three divisions of the world; and that this, says (the Peratic), is what is spoken: "It pleased him that in him should dwell all fulness bodily," and in Him the entire Divinity resides of the triad as thus divided.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 7:10
verses.text: For, he says, that from the two superjacent worlds—namely, from that (portion of the triad) which is unbegotten, and from that which is self-producing—there have been conveyed down into this world in which we are, seeds of all sorts of potentialities.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 7:11
verses.text: What, however, the mode of the descent is, we shall afterwards declare.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 7:12
verses.text: (The Peratic) then says that Christ descended from above from unorigination, that by His descent all things triply divided might be saved.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 7:13
verses.text: For some things, he says, being borne down from above, will ascend through Him, whereas whatever (beings) form plots against those which are carried down from above are cast off, and being placed in a state of punishment, are renounced.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 7:14
verses.text: This, he says, is what is spoken: "For the Son of man came not into the world to destroy the world, but that the world through Him might be saved".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 7:15
verses.text: The world, he says, he denominates those two parts that are situated above, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 7:16
verses.text: , both the unbegotten (portion of the triad), and the self-produced one.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 7:17
verses.text: And when Scripture, he says, uses the words, "that we may not be condemned with the world," it alludes to the third portion of (the triad, that is) the formal world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 7:18
verses.text: For the third portion, which he styles the world (in which we are), must perish; but the two (remaining portions), which are situated above, must be rescued from corruption.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:1
verses.text: The Peratae Derive Their System from the Astrologers; This Proved by a Statement of the Astrological Theories of the Zodiac; Hence the Terminology of the Peratic Heretics.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:2
verses.text: Let us, then, in the first place, learn how (the Peratists), deriving this doctrine from astrologers, act despitefully towards Christ, working destruction for those who follow them in an error of this description.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:3
verses.text: For the astrologers, alleging that there is one world, divide it into the twelve fixed portions of the zodiacal signs, and call the world of the fixed zodiacal signs one immoveable world; and the other they affirm to be a world of erratic (signs), both in power, and position, and number, and that it extends as far as the moon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:4
verses.text: And (they lay down), that (one) world derives from (the other) world a certain power, and mutual participation (in that power), and that the subjacent obtain this participation from the superjacent (portions).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:5
verses.text: In order, however, that what is (here) asserted may be perspicuous, I shall one by one employ those very expressions of the astrologers; (and in doing so) I shall only be reminding my readers of statements previously made in the department of the work where we have explained the entire art of the astrologers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:6
verses.text: What, then, the opinions are which those (speculators) entertain, are as follow:—  (Their doctrine is), that from an emanation of the stars the generations of the subjacent (parts) is consummated.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:7
