verses.text: For, as they wistfully gazed upward upon heaven, the Chaldeans asserted that (the seven stars) contain a reason for the efficient causes of the occurrence of all the events that happen unto us, and that the parts of the fixed zodiacal signs co-operate (in this influence).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:8
verses.text: Into twelve (parts they divide the zodiacal circle), and each zodiacal sign into thirty portions, and each portion into sixty diminutive parts; for so they denominate the very smallest parts, and those that are indivisible.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:9
verses.text: And of the zodiacal signs, they term some male, but others feminine; and some with two bodies, but others not so; and some tropical, whereas others firm.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:10
verses.text: The male signs, then, are either feminine, which possess a co-operative nature for the procreation of males, (or are themselves productive of females.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:11
verses.text: ) For Aries is a male zodiacal sign, but Taurus female; and the rest (are denominated) according to the same analogy, some male, but others female.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:12
verses.text: And I suppose that the Pythagoreans, being swayed from such (considerations), style the Monad male, and the Duad female; and, again, the Triad male, and analogically the remainder of the even and odd numbers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:13
verses.text: Some, however, dividing each zodiacal sign into twelve parts, employ almost the same method.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:14
verses.text: For example, in Aries, they style the first of the twelve parts both Aries and a male, but the second both Taurus and a female, and the third both Gemini and a male; and the same plan is pursued in the case of the rest of the parts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:15
verses.text: And they assert that there are signs with two bodies, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:16
verses.text: , Gemini and the signs diametrically opposite, namely Sagittarius, and Virgo, and Pisces, and that the rest have not two bodies.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:17
verses.text: And (they state) that some are likewise tropical, and when the sun stands in these, he causes great turnings of the surrounding (sign).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:18
verses.text: Aries is a sign of this description, and that which is diametrically opposite to it, just as Libra, and Capricorn, and Cancer.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:19
verses.text: For in Aries is the vernal turning, and in Capricorn that of winter, and in Cancer that of summer, and in Libra that of autumn.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:20
verses.text: The details, however, concerning this system we have minutely explained in the book preceding this; and from it any one who wishes instruction (on the point), may learn how it is that the originators of this Peratic heresy, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:21
verses.text: , Euphrates the Peratic, and Celbes the Carystian, have, in the transference (into their own system of opinions from these sources), made alterations in name only, while in reality they have put forward similar tenets.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:22
verses.text: (Nay more), they have, with immoderate zeal, themselves devoted (their attention) to the art (of the astrologers).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:23
verses.text: For also the astrologers speak of the limits of the stars, in which they assert that the dominant stars have greater influence; as, for instance, on some they act injuriously, while on others they act well.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:24
verses.text: And of these they denominate some malicious, and some beneficent.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:25
verses.text: And (stars) are said to look upon one another, and to harmonize with each other, so that they appear according to (the shape of) a triangle or square.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:26
verses.text: The stars, looking on one another, are figured according to (the shape of) a triangle, having an intervening distance of the extent of three zodiacal signs; whereas (those that have an interval of) two zodiacal signs are figured according to (the shape of) a square.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:27
verses.text: And (their doctrine is), that as in the same way as in a man, the subjacent parts sympathize with the head, and the head likewise sympathizes with the subjacent parts, so all terrestrial (sympathize) with super-lunar objects.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:28
verses.text: But (the astrologers go further than this); for there exists (according to them) a certain difference and incompatibility between these, so as that they do not involve one and the same union.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:29
verses.text: This combination and divergence of the stars, which is a Chaldean (tenet), has been arrogated to themselves by those of whom we have previously spoken.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:30
verses.text: Now these, falsifying the name of truth, proclaim as a doctrine of Christ an insurrection of aeons and revolts of good into (the ranks of) evil powers; and they speak of the confederations of good powers with wicked ones.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:31
verses.text: Denominating them, therefore, Toparchai and Proastioi, and (though thus) framing for themselves very many other names not suggested (to them from other sources), they have yet unskilfully systematized the entire imaginary doctrine of the astrologers concerning the stars.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:32
verses.text: And since they have introduced a supposition pregnant with immense error, they shall be refuted through the instrumentality of our admirable arrangement.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 8:33
verses.text: For I shall set down, in contrast with the previously mentioned Chaldaic art of the astrologers, some of the Peratic treatises, from which, by means of comparison, there will be an opportunity of perceiving how the Peratic doctrines are those confessedly of the astrologers, not of Christ.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:1
verses.text: System of the Peratae Explained Out of One of Their Own Books.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:2
verses.text: It seems, then, expedient to set forth a certain one of the books held in repute amongst them, in which the following passage occurs: "I am a voice of arousal from slumber in the age of night.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:3
verses.text: Henceforward I commence to strip the power which is from chaos.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:4
verses.text: The power is that of the lowest depth of mud, which uprears the slime of the incorruptible (and) humid expanse of space.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:5
verses.text: And it is the entire power of the convulsion, which, ever in motion, and presenting the colour of water, whirls things on that are stationary, restrains things tremulous, sets things free as they proceed, lightens things as they abide, removes things on the increase, a faithful steward of the track of the breezes, enjoying the things disgorged from the twelve eyes of the law, (and) manifesting a seal to the power which along with itself distributes the downborne invisible waters, and has been called Thalassa.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:6
verses.text: This power ignorance has been accustomed to denominate Cronus, guarded with chains because he tightly bound the fold of the dense and misty and obscure and murky Tartarus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:7
verses.text: According to the image of this were produced Cepheus, Prometheus, (and) Japetus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:8
verses.text: The Power to which has been entrusted Thalassa is hermaphrodite.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:9
verses.text: And it fastens the hissing sound arising from the twelve mouths into twelve pipes, and pours it forth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:10
verses.text: And the power itself is subtle, and removes the controlling, boisterous, upward motion (of the sea), and seals the tracks of its paths, lest (any antagonistic power) should wage war or introduce any alteration.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:11
verses.text: The tempestuous daughter of this one is a faithful protectress of all sorts of waters.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:12
verses.text: Her name is Chorzar.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:13
verses.text: Ignorance is in the habit of styling this (power) Neptune, according to whose image was produced Glaucus, Melicertes, Ino, Nebroë.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:14
verses.text: He that is encircled with the pyramid of twelve angels, and darkens the gate into the pyramid with various colours, and completes the entire in the sable hues of Night: this one ignorance denominated Cronus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:15
verses.text: And his ministers were five,—first U, second Aoai, third Uo, fourth Uoab, fifth…Other trustworthy managers (there are) of his province of night and day, who repose in their own power.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:16
verses.text: Ignorance denominated these the erratic stars, from whom depends a corruptible generation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:17
verses.text: Manager of the rising of the star is Carphacasemeocheir, (and) Eccabbacara (is the same).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:18
verses.text: Ignorance is in the habit of denominating these Curetes chief of the winds; third in order is Ariel, according to whose image was generated aeolus, Briares.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:19
verses.text: And chief of the twelve-houred nocturnal (power) is Soclan, whom ignorance is accustomed to style Osiris; (and) according to the image of this one was born Admetus, Medea, Helen, aethusa.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:20
verses.text: Chief of the twelve-houred diurnal power is Euno.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:21
verses.text: This is manager of the rising of the star Protocamarus and of the ethereal (region), but ignorance has denominated him Isis.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:22
verses.text: A sign of this one is the Dog-star, according to whose image were born Ptolemaeus son of Arsinoe, Didyma, Cleopatra, and Olympias.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:23
verses.text: God's right-hand power is that which ignorance has denominated Rhea, according to whose image were produced Attis, Mygdon, (and) oenone.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:24
verses.text: The left-hand power has lordship over sustenance, and ignorance is in the habit of styling this Ceres, (while) her name is Bena; and according to the image of this one were born Celeus, Triptolemus, Misyr, and Praxidica.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:25
verses.text: The right-hand power has lordship over fruits.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:26
verses.text: This one ignorance has denominated Mena, according to whose image were born Bumegas, Ostanes, Mercury Trismegistus, Curites, Petosiris, Zodarium, Berosus, Astrampsuchus, (and) Zoroaster.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:27
verses.text: The left-hand power is (lord) of fire, (and) ignorance has denominated this one Vulcan, according to whose image were born Ericthonius, Achilles, Capaneus, Phaëthon, Meleager, Tydeus, Enceladus, Raphael, Suriel, (and) Omphale.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:28
verses.text: There are three intermediate powers suspended from air, authors of generation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:29
verses.text: These ignorance has been in the habit of denominating Fates; and according to the image of these were produced the house of Priam, the house of Laius, Ino, Autonoe, Agave, Athamas, Procne, Danaides, and Peliades.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:30
verses.text: A power (there is) hermaphrodite, always continuing in infancy, never waxing old, cause of beauty, pleasure, maturity, desire, and concupiscence; and ignorance has been accustomed to style this Eros, according to whose image were born Paris, Narcissus, Ganymede, Endymion, Tithonus, Icarius, Leda, Amymone, Thetis, Hesperides, Jason, Leander, (and) Hero".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 9:31
verses.text: These are Proastioi up to aether, for with this title also he inscribes the book.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 10

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 10:1
verses.text: The Peratic Heresy Nominally Different from Astrology, But Really the Same System Allegorized.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 10:2
verses.text: It has been easily made evident to all, that the heresy of the Peratae is altered in name only from the (art) of the astrologers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 10:3
verses.text: And the rest of the books of these (heretics) contain the same method, if it were agreeable to any one to wade through them all.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 10:4
verses.text: For, as I said, they suppose that the causes of the generation of all begotten things are things unbegotten and superjacent, and that the world with us has been produced after the mode of emanation, which (world) they denominate formal.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 10:5
verses.text: And (they maintain) that all those stars together which are beheld in the firmament have been causes of the generation of this world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 10:6
verses.text: They have, however, altered the name of these, as one may perceive from the Proastioi by means of a comparison (of the two systems).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 10:7
verses.text: And secondly, according to the same method as that whereby the world was made from a supernal emanation, they affirm that in this manner objects here derive from the emanation of the stars their generation, and corruption, and arrangement.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 10:8
verses.text: Since, then, astrologers are acquainted with the horoscope, and meridian, and setting, and the point opposite the meridian; and since these stars occupy at different times different positions in space, on account of the perpetual revolution of the universe, there are (necessarily) at different periods different declinations towards a centre, and (different) ascensions to centres.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 10:9
verses.text: (Now the Peratic heretics), affixing an allegorical import to this arrangement of the astrologers, delineate the centre, as it were, a god and monad and lord over universal generation, whereas the declination (is regarded by them as a power) on the left, and ascension on the right.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 10:10
verses.text: When any one, therefore, falling in with the treatises of these (heretics), finds mention among them of right or left power, let him recur to the centre, and the declination, and the ascension (of the Chaldean sages, and) he will clearly observe that the entire system of these (Peratae) consists of the astrological doctrine.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:1
verses.text: Why They Call Themselves Peratae; Their Theory of Generation Supported by an Appeal to Antiquity; Their Interpretation of the Exodus of Israel; Their System of "The Serpent;" Deduced by Them from Scripture; This the Real Import of the Doctrines of the Astrologers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:2
verses.text: They denominate themselves, however, Peratae, imagining that none of those things existing by generation can escape the determined lot for those things that derive their existence from generation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:3
verses.text: For if, says (the Peratic), anything be altogether begotten, it also perishes, as also is the opinion of the Sibyl.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:4
verses.text: But we alone, he says, who are conversant with the necessity of generation, and the paths through which man has entered into the world, and who have been accurately instructed (in these matters), we alone are competent to proceed through and pass beyond destruction.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:5
verses.text: But water, he says, is destruction; nor did the world, he says, perish by any other thing quicker than by water.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:6
verses.text: Water, however, is that which rolls around among the Proastioi, (and) they assert (it to be) Cronus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:7
verses.text: For such a power, he says, is of the colour of water; and this power, he says—that is, Cronus—none of those things existent by generation can escape.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:8
verses.text: For Cronus is a cause to every generation, in regard of succumbing under destruction, and there could not exist (an instance of) generation in which Cronus does not interfere.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:9
verses.text: This, he says, is what the poets also affirm, and what even appals the gods:—  "For know, he says, this earth and spacious heaven above,  And Styx' flooded water, which is the oath  That greatest is, and dreaded most by gods of happy life".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:10
verses.text: And not only, he says, do the poets make this statement, but already also the very wisest men among the Greeks.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:11
verses.text: And Heraclitus is even one of these, employing the following words: "For to souls water becomes death".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:12
verses.text: This death, (the Peratic) says, seizes the Egyptians in the Red Sea, along with their chariots.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:13
verses.text: All, however, who are ignorant (of this fact), he says, are Egyptians.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:14
verses.text: And this, they assert, is the departure from Egypt, (that is,) from the body.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:15
verses.text: For they suppose little Egypt to be body, and that it crosses the Red Sea—that is, the water of corruption, which is Cronus—and that it reaches a place beyond the Red Sea, that is, generation; and that it comes into the wilderness, that is, that it attains a condition independent of generation, where there exist promiscuously all the gods of destruction and the God of salvation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:16
verses.text: Now, he says, the stars are the gods of destruction, which impose upon existent things the necessity of alterable generation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:17
verses.text: These, he says, Moses denominated serpents of the wilderness, which gnaw and utterly ruin those who imagined that they had crossed the Red Sea.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:18
verses.text: To those, then, he says, who of the children of Israel were bitten in the wilderness, Moses exhibited the real and perfect serpent; and they who believed on this serpent were not bitten in the wilderness, that is, (were not assailed) by (evil) powers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:19
verses.text: No one therefore, he says, is there who is able to save and deliver those that come forth from Egypt, that is, from the body and from this world, unless alone the serpent that is perfect and replete with fulness.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:20
verses.text: Upon this (serpent), he says, he who fixes his hope is not destroyed by the snakes of the wilderness, that is, by the gods of generation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:21
verses.text: (This statement) is written, he says, in a book of Moses.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:22
verses.text: This serpent, he says, is the power that attended Moses, the rod that was turned into a serpent.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:23
verses.text: The serpents, however, of the magicians—(that is,) the gods of destruction—withstood the power of Moses in Egypt, but the rod of Moses reduced them all to subjection and slew them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:24
verses.text: This universal serpent is, he says, the wise discourse of Eve.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:25
verses.text: This, he says, is the mystery of Edem, this the river of Edem; this the mark that was set upon Cain, that any one who findeth him might not kill him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:26
verses.text: This, he says, is Cain, whose sacrifice the god of this world did not accept.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:27
verses.text: The gory sacrifice, however, of Abel he approved of; for the ruler of this world rejoices in (offerings of) blood.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:28
verses.text: This, he says, is he who appeared in the last days, in form of a man, in the times of Herod, being born after the likeness of Joseph, who was sold by the hand of his brethren, to whom alone belonged the coat of many colours.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:29
verses.text: This, he says, is he who is according to the likeness of Esau, whose garment—he not being himself present—was blessed; who did not receive, he says, the benediction uttered by him of enfeebled vision.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:30
verses.text: He acquired, however, wealth from a source independent of this, receiving nothing from him whose eyes were dim; and Jacob saw his countenance, as a man beholds the face of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:31
verses.text: In regard of this, he says, it has been written that "Nebrod was a mighty hunter before the Lord".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:32
verses.text: And there are, he says, many who closely imitate this (Nimrod): as numerous are they as the gnawing (serpents) which were seen in the wilderness by the children of Israel, from which that perfect serpent which Moses set up delivered those that were bitten.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:33
verses.text: This, he says, is that which has been declared: "In the same manner as Moses lifted up the serpent in the wilderness, so also must the Son of man be lifted up".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:34
verses.text: According to the likeness of this was made in the desert the brazen serpent which Moses set up.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:35
verses.text: Of this alone, he says, the image is in heaven, always conspicuous in light.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:36
verses.text: This, he says, is the great beginning respecting which Scripture has spoken.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:37
verses.text: Concerning this, he says it has been declared: "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:38
verses.text: This was in the beginning with God, all things were made by Him, and without Him was not one thing that was made.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:39
verses.text: And what was formed in Him is life".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:40
verses.text: And in Him, he says, has been formed Eve; (now) Eve is life.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:41
verses.text: This, however, he says, is Eve, mother of all living,—a common nature, that is, of gods, angels, immortals, mortals, irrational creatures, (and) rational ones.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:42
verses.text: For, he says, the expression "all" he uttered of all (existences).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:43
verses.text: And if the eyes of any, he says, are blessed, this one, looking upward on the firmament, will behold at the mighty summit of heaven the beauteous image of the serpent, turning itself, and becoming an originating principle of every (species of) motion to all things that are being produced.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:44
verses.text: He will (thereby) know that without him nothing consists, either of things in heaven, or things on earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:45
verses.text: or things under the earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:46
verses.text: Not night, not moon, not fruits, not generation, not wealth, not sustenance, not anything at all of existent things, is without his guidance.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:47
verses.text: In regard of this, he says, is the great wonder which is beheld in the firmament by those who are able to observe it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:48
verses.text: For, he says, at this top of his head, a fact which is more incredible than all things to those who are ignorant, "are setting and rising mingled one with other".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:49
verses.text: This it is in regard of which ignorance is in the habit of affirming: in heaven  "Draco revolves, marvel mighty of monster dread".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:50
verses.text: And on both sides of him have been placed Corona and Lyra; and above, near the top itself of the head, is visible the piteous man "Engonasis,"  "Holding the right foot's end of Draco fierce".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 11:51
verses.text: And at the back of Engonasis is an imperfect serpent, with both hands tightly secured by Anguitenens, and being hindered from touching Corona that lies beside the perfect serpent.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:1
verses.text: Compendious Statement of the Doctrines of the Peratae.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:2
verses.text: This is the diversified wisdom of the Peratic heresy, which it is difficult to declare in its entirety, so intricate is it on account of its seeming to consist of the astrological art.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:3
verses.text: As far forth, then, as this is possible, we shall briefly explain the whole force of this (heresy).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:4
verses.text: In order, however, that we may by a compendious statement elucidate the entire doctrine of these persons, it appears expedient to subjoin the following observations.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:5
verses.text: According to them, the universe is Father, Son, (and) Matter; (but) each of these three has endless capacities in itself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:6
verses.text: Intermediate, then, between the Matter and the Father sits the Son, the Word, the Serpent, always being in motion towards the unmoved Father, and (towards) Matter itself in motion.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:7
verses.text: And at one time he is turned towards the Father, and receives the powers into his own person; but at another time takes up these powers, and is turned towards Matter.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:8
verses.text: And Matter, (though) devoid of attribute, and being unfashioned, moulds (into itself) forms from the Son which the Son moulded from the Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:9
verses.text: But the Son derives shape from the Father after a mode ineffable, and unspeakable, and unchangeable; (that is,) in such a manner as Moses says that the colours of the conceived (kine) flowed from the rods which were fixed in the drinking-troughs.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:10
verses.text: And in like manner, again, that capacities flowed also from the Son into Matter, similarly to the power in reference to conception which came from the rods upon the conceived (kine).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:11
verses.text: And the difference of colours, and the dissimilarity which flowed from the rods through the waters upon the sheep, is, he says, the difference of corruptible and incorruptible generation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:12
verses.text: As, however, one who paints from nature, though he takes nothing away from animals, transfers by his pencil all forms to the canvas; so the Son, by a power which belongs to himself, transfers paternal marks from the Father into Matter.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:13
verses.text: All the paternal marks are here, and there are not any more.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:14
verses.text: For if any one, he says, of those (beings) which are here will have strength to perceive that he is a paternal mark transferred hither from above, (and that he is) incarnate—just as by the conception resulting from the rod a something white is produced,—he is of the same substance altogether with the Father in heaven, and returns thither.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:15
verses.text: If, however, he may not happen upon this doctrine, neither will he understand the necessity of generation, just as an abortion born at night will perish at night.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:16
verses.text: When, therefore, he says, the Saviour observes, "your Father which is in heaven," he alludes to that one from whom the Son deriving his characteristics has transferred them hither.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:17
verses.text: When, however, (Jesus) remarks, "Your father is a murderer from the beginning," he alludes to the Ruler and Demiurge of matter, who, appropriating the marks delivered from the Son, generated him here who from the beginning was a murderer, for his work causes corruption and death.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:18
verses.text: No one, then, he says, can be saved or return (into heaven) without the Son, and the Son is the Serpent.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:19
verses.text: For as he brought down from above the paternal marks, so again he carries up from thence those marks roused from a dormant condition and rendered paternal characteristics, substantial ones from the unsubstantial Being, transferring them hither from thence.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:20
verses.text: This, he says, is what is spoken: "I am the door".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:21
verses.text: And he transfers (those marks), he says, to those who close the eyelid, as the naphtha drawing the fire in every direction towards itself; nay rather, as the magnet (attracting) the iron and not anything else, or just as the backbone of the sea falcon, the gold and nothing else, or as the chaff is led by the amber.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:22
verses.text: In this manner, he says, is the portrayed, perfect, and consubstantial genus drawn again from the world by the Serpent; nor does he (attract) anything else, as it has been sent down by him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:23
verses.text: For a proof of this, they adduce the anatomy of the brain, assimilating, from the fact of its immobility, the brain itself to the Father, and the cerebellum to the Son, because of its being moved and being of the form of (the head of) a serpent.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:24
verses.text: And they allege that this (cerebellum), by an ineffable and inscrutable process, attracts through the pineal gland the spiritual and life-giving substance emanating from the vaulted chamber (in which the brain is embedded).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:25
verses.text: And on receiving this, the cerebellum in an ineffable manner imparts the ideas, just as the Son does, to matter; or, in other words, the seeds and the genera of the things produced according to the flesh flow along into the spinal marrow.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:26
verses.text: Employing this exemplar, (the heretics) seem to adroitly introduce their secret mysteries, which are delivered in silence.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 12:27
verses.text: Now it would be impious for us to declare these; yet it is easy to form an idea of them, by reason of the many statements that have been made.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 13

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 13:1
verses.text: But since I consider that I have plainly explained the Peratic heresy, and by many (arguments) have rendered evident (a system that hitherto) has always escaped notice, and is altogether a tissue of fable, and one that disguises its own peculiar venom, it seems expedient to advance no further statement beyond those already put forward; for the opinions propounded by (the heretics) themselves are sufficient for their own condemnation.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:1
verses.text: The System of the Sethians; Their Triad of Infinite Principles; Their Heresy Explained; Their Interpretation of the Incarnation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:2
verses.text: Let us then see what the Sithians affirm.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:3
verses.text: To these it appears that there are three definite principles of the universe, and that each of these principles possesses infinite powers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:4
verses.text: And when they speak of powers let him that heareth take into account that they make this statement.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:5
verses.text: Everything whatsoever you discern by an act of intelligence, or also omit (to discern) as not being understood, this by nature is fitted to become each of the principles, as in the human soul every art whatsoever which is made the subject of instruction.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:6
verses.text: Just for instance, he says, this child will be a musician, having waited the requisite time for (acquiring a knowledge of) the harp; or a geometrician, (having previously undergone the necessary study for acquiring a knowledge) of geometry; (or) a grammarian, (after having sufficiently studied) grammar; (or) a workman, (having acquired a practical acquaintance) with a handicraftsman's business; and to one brought into contact with the rest of the arts a similar occurrence will take place.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:7
verses.text: Now of principles, he says, the substances are light and darkness; and of these, spirit is intermediate without admixture.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:8
verses.text: The spirit, however, is that which has its appointed place in the midst of darkness which is below, and light which is above.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:9
verses.text: It is not spirit as a current of wind, or some gentle breeze that can be felt; but, as it were, some odour of ointment or of incense formed out of a compound.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:10
verses.text: (It is) a subtle power, that insinuates itself by means of some impulsive quality in a fragrance, which is inconceivable and better than could be expressed by words.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:11
verses.text: Since, however, light is above and darkness below, and spirit is intermediate in such a way as stated between these; and since light is so constituted, that, like a ray of the sun, it shines from above upon the underlying darkness; and again, since the fragrance of the spirit, holding an intermediate place, is extended and carried in every direction, as in the case of incense-offerings placed upon fire, we detect the fragrance that is being wafted in every direction: when, I say, there is a power of this description belonging unto the principles which are classified under three divisions, the power of spirit and light simultaneously exists in the darkness that is situated underneath them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:12
verses.text: But the darkness is a terrible water, into which light is absorbed and translated into a nature of the same description with spirit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:13
verses.text: The darkness, however, is not devoid of intelligence, but altogether reflective, and is conscious that, where the light has been abstracted from the darkness, the darkness remains isolated, invisible, obscure, impotent, inoperative, (and) feeble.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:14
verses.text: Wherefore it is constrained, by all its reflection and understanding, to collect into itself the lustre and scintillation of light with the fragrance of the spirit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:15
verses.text: And it is possible to behold an image of the nature of these in the human countenance; for instance, the pupil of the eye, dark from the subjacent humours, (but) illuminated with spirit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:16
verses.text: As, then, the darkness seeks after the splendour, that it may keep in bondage the spark, and may have perceptive power, so the light and spirit seek after the power that belongs to themselves, and strive to uprear, and towards each other to carry up their intermingled powers into the dark and formidable water lying underneath.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:17
verses.text: But all the powers of the three originating principles, which are as regards number indefinitely infinite, are each according to its own substance reflective and intelligent, unnumbered in multitude.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:18
verses.text: And since what are reflective and intelligent are numberless in multitude, while they continue by themselves, they are all at rest.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:19
verses.text: If, however, power approaches power, the dissimilarity of (what is set in) juxtaposition produces a certain motion and energy, which are formed from the motion resulting from the concourse effected by the juxtaposition of the coalescing powers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:20
verses.text: For the concourse of the powers ensues, just like any mark of a seal that is impressed by means of the concourse correspondingly with (the seal) which prints the figure on the substances that are brought up (into contact with it).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:21
verses.text: Since, therefore, the powers of the three principles are infinite in number, and from infinite powers (arise) infinite concourses, images of infinite seals are necessarily produced.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:22
verses.text: These images, therefore, are the forms of the different sorts of animals.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:23
verses.text: From the first great concourse, then, of the three principles, ensues a certain great form, a seal of heaven and earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:24
verses.text: The heaven and the earth have a figure similar to the womb, having a navel in the midst; and if, he says, any one is desirous of bringing this figure under the organ of vision, let him artfully scrutinize the pregnant womb of whatsoever animal he wishes, and he will discover an image of the heaven and the earth, and of the things which in the midst of all are unalterably situated underneath.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:25
verses.text: (And so it is, that the first great concourse of the three principles) has produced such a figure of heaven and earth as is similar to a womb after the first coition.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:26
verses.text: But, again, in the midst of the heaven and the earth have been generated infinite concourses of powers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:27
verses.text: And each concourse did not effect and fashion anything else than a seal of heaven and earth similar to a womb.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:28
verses.text: But, again, in the earth, from the infinite seals are produced infinite crowds of various animals.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:29
verses.text: But into all this infinity of the different animals under heaven is diffused and distributed, along with the light, the fragrance of the Spirit from above.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:30
verses.text: From the water, therefore, has been produced a first-begotten originating principle, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:31
verses.text: , wind, (which is) violent and boisterous, and a cause of all generation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:32
verses.text: For producing a sort of ferment in the waters, (the wind) uplifts waves out of the waters; and the motion of the waves, just as when some impulsive power of pregnancy is the origin of the production of a man or mind, is caused when (the ocean), excited by the impulsive power of spirit, is propelled forward.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:33
verses.text: When, however, this wave that has been raised out of the water by the wind, and rendered pregnant in its nature, has within itself obtained the power, possessed by the female, of generation, it holds together the light scattered from above along with the fragrance of the spirit—that is, mind moulded in the different species.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:34
verses.text: And this (light) is a perfect God, who from the unbegotten radiance above, and from the spirit, is borne down into human nature as into a temple, by the impulsive power of Nature, and by the motion of wind.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:35
verses.text: And it is produced from water being commingled and blended with bodies as if it were a salt of existent things, and a light of darkness.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:36
verses.text: And it struggles to be released from bodies, and is not able to find liberation and an egress for itself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:37
verses.text: For a very diminutive spark, a severed splinter from above like the ray of a star, has been mingled in the much compounded waters of many (existences), as, says he, (David) remarks in a psalm.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:38
verses.text: Every thought, then, and solicitude actuating the supernal light is as to how and in what manner mind may be liberated, by the death of the depraved and dark body, from the Father that is below, which is the wind that with noise and tumult uplifted the waves, and who generated a perfect mind his own Son; not, however, being his peculiar (offspring) substantially.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:39
verses.text: For he was a ray (sent down) from above, from that perfect light, (and) was overpowered in the dark, and formidable, and bitter, and defiled water; and he is a luminous spirit borne down over the water.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:40
verses.text: When, therefore, the waves that have been upreared from the waters have received within themselves the power of generation possessed by females, they contain, as a certain womb, in different species, the infused radiance, so as that it is visible in the case of all animals.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:41
verses.text: But the wind, at the same time fierce and formidable, whirling along, is, in respect of its hissing sound, like a serpent.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:42
verses.text: First, then, from the wind—that is, from the serpent—has resulted the originating principle of generation in the manner declared, all things having simultaneously received the principle of generation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:43
verses.text: After, then, the light and the spirit had been received, he says, into the polluted and baneful (and) disordered womb, the serpent—the wind of the darkness, the first-begotten of the waters—enters within and produces man, and the impure womb neither loves nor recognises any other form.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:44
verses.text: The perfect Word of supernal light being therefore assimilated (in form) to the beast, (that is,) the serpent, entered into the defiled womb, having deceived (the womb) through the similitude of the beast itself, in order that (the Word) may loose the chains that encircle the perfect mind which has been begotten amidst impurity of womb by the primal offspring of water, (namely,) serpent, wind, (and) beast.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:45
verses.text: This, he says, is the form of the servant, and this the necessity of the Word of God coming down into the womb of a virgin.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:46
verses.text: But he says it is not sufficient that the Perfect Man, the Word, has entered into the womb of a virgin, and loosed the pangs which were in that darkness.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:47
verses.text: Nay, more than this was requisite; for after his entrance into the foul mysteries of the womb, he was washed, and drank of the cup of life-giving bubbling water.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 14:48
verses.text: And it was altogether needful that he should drink who was about to strip off the servile form, and assume celestial raiment.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:1
verses.text: The Sethians Support Their Doctrines by an Allegorical Interpretation of Scripture; Their System Really Derived from Natural Philosophers and from the Orphic Rites; Adopt the Homeric Cosmogony.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:2
verses.text: These are the statements which the patrons of the Sethian doctrines make, as far as it is possible to declare in a few words.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:3
verses.text: Their system, however, is made up (of tenets) from natural (philosophers), and of expressions uttered in reference to different other subjects; and transferring (the sense of) these to the Eternal Logos, they explain them as we have declared.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:4
verses.text: But they assert likewise that Moses confirms their doctrine when he says, "Darkness, and mist, and tempest".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:5
verses.text: These, (the Sethian) says, are the three principles (of our system); or when he states that three were born in paradise—Adam, Eve, the serpent; or when he speaks of three (persons, namely) Cain, Abel, Seth; and again of three (others)—Shem, Ham, Japheth; or when he mentions three patriarchs—Abraham, Isaac, Jacob; or when he speaks of the existence of three days before sun and moon; or when he mentions three laws—prohibitory, permissive, and adjudicatory of punishment.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:6
verses.text: Now, a prohibitory law is as follows: "Of every tree that is in paradise thou mayest freely eat; but of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil thou mayest not eat".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:7
verses.text: But in the passage, "Come forth from thy land and from thy kindred, and hither into a land which I shall show thee," this law, he says, is permissive; for one who is so disposed may depart, and one who is not so disposed may remain.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:8
verses.text: But a law adjudicatory of punishment is that which makes the following declaration: "Thou shalt not commit adultery, thou shalt not kill, thou shalt not steal;" for a penalty is awarded to each of these acts of wickedness.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:9
verses.text: The entire system of their doctrine, however, is (derived) from the ancient theologians Musaeus, and Linus, and Orpheus, who elucidates especially the ceremonies of initiation, as well as the mysteries themselves.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:10
verses.text: For their doctrine concerning the womb is also the tenet of Orpheus; and the (idea of the) navel, which is harmony, is (to be found) with the same symbolism attached to it in the Bacchanalian orgies of Orpheus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:11
verses.text: But prior to the observance of the mystic rite of Celeus, and Triptolemus, and Ceres, and Proserpine, and Bacchus in Eleusis, these orgies have been celebrated and handed down to men in Phlium of Attica.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:12
verses.text: For antecedent to the Eleusinian mysteries, there are (enacted) in Phlium the orgies of her denominated the "Great (Mother)".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:13
verses.text: There is, however, a portico in this (city), and on the portico is inscribed a representation, (visible) up to the present day, of all the words which are spoken (on such occasions).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:14
verses.text: Many, then, of the words inscribed upon that portico are those respecting which Plutarch institutes discussions in his ten books against Empedocles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:15
verses.text: And in the greater number of these books is also drawn the representation of a certain aged man, grey-haired, winged, having his pudendum erectum, pursuing a retreating woman of azure colour.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:16
verses.text: And over the aged man is the inscription "phaos ruentes," and over the woman "pereëphicola".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:17
verses.text: But "phaos ruentes" appears to be the light (which exists), according to the doctrine of the Sethians, and "phicola" the darkish water; while the space in the midst of these seems to be a harmony constituted from the spirit that is placed between.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:18
verses.text: The name, however, of "phaos ruentes" manifests, as they allege, the flow from above of the light downwards.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:19
verses.text: Wherefore one may reasonably assert that the Sethians celebrate rites among themselves, very closely bordering upon those orgies of the "Great (Mother" which are observed among) the Phliasians.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:20
verses.text: And the poet likewise seems to bear his testimony to this triple division, when he remarks, "And all things have been triply divided, and everything obtains its (proper) distinction;" that is, each member of the threefold division has obtained (a particular) capacity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:21
verses.text: But now, as regards the tenet that the subjacent water below, which is dark, ought, because the light has set (over it), to convey upwards and receive the spark borne down from (the light) itself; in the assertion of this tenet, I say, the all-wise Sethians appear to derive (their opinion) from Homer:—  "By earth I sware, and yon broad Heaven above,  And Stygian stream beneath, the weightiest oath  Of solemn power, to bind the blessed gods".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:22
verses.text: That is, according to Homer, the gods suppose water to be loathsome and horrible.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 15:23
verses.text: Now, similar to this is the doctrine of the Sethians, which affirms (water) to be formidable to the mind.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:1
verses.text: The Sethian Theory Concerning "Mixture" And "Composition;" Application of It to Christ; Illustration from the Well of Ampa.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:2
verses.text: These, and other assertions similar to these, are made (by the Sethians) in their interminable commentaries.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:3
verses.text: They, however, persuade their disciples to become conversant with the theory respecting composition and mixture.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:4
verses.text: But this theory has formed a subject of meditation to many, but (among others) also to Andronicus the Peripatetic.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:5
verses.text: The Sethians, then, affirm that the theory concerning composition and mixture is constituted according to the following method: The luminous ray from above is intermingled, and the very diminutive spark is delicately blended in the dark waters beneath; and (both of these) become united, and are formed into one compound mass, just as a single savour (results) from the mixture of many incense-offerings in the fire, and (just as) an adept, by having a test in an acute sense of smell, ought to be able from the single odour of the incense to distinguish accurately each (ingredient) of the incense-offerings that have been mingled in the fire,—whether, for example, storax, and myrrh, and frankincense, or whatever other (ingredient) may be mixed (in the incense).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:6
verses.text: They, however, employ also other examples, saying both that brass is mixed with gold, and that some art has been discovered which separates the brass from the gold.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:7
verses.text: And, in like manner, if tin or brass, or any substance homogeneous with it, be discovered mixed with silver, these likewise, by some art superior to that of mixing, are distinguished.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:8
verses.text: But already some one also distinguishes water mingled with wine.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:9
verses.text: So, say they, though all things are commingled, they are capable of being separated.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:10
verses.text: Nay, but, he says, derive the same lesson from the case of animals.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:11
verses.text: For when the animal is dead, each of its parts is separated; and when dissolution takes place, the animal in this way vanishes.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:12
verses.text: This is, he says, what has been spoken: "I came not to send peace on the earth, but a sword,"—that is, the division and separation of the things that have been commingled.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:13
verses.text: For each of the things that have been commingled is separated and divided when it reaches its proper place.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:14
verses.text: For as there is one place of mixture for all animals, so also has there been established one (locality) of separation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:15
verses.text: And, he says, no one is aware of this (place), save we alone that have been born again, spiritual, not carnal, whose citizenship is in heaven above.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:16
verses.text: In this manner insinuating themselves, they corrupt their pupils, partly by misusing the words spoken (by themselves), while they wickedly pervert, to serve any purpose they wish, what has been admirably said (in Scripture); and partly by concealing their nefarious conduct, by means of whatever comparisons they please.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:17
verses.text: All these things, then, he says, that have been commingled, possess, as has been declared, their own particular place, and hurry towards their own peculiar (substances), as iron towards the magnet, and the chaff to the vicinity of amber, and the gold to the spur of the sea falcon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:18
verses.text: In like manner, the rayof light which has been commingled with the water, having obtained from discipline and instruction its own proper locality, hastens towards the Logos that comes from above in servile form; and along with the Logos exists as a logos in that place where the Logos is still: (the light, I say, hastens to the Logos with greater speed) than the iron towards the magnet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:19
verses.text: And that these things, he says, are so, and that all things that have been commingled are separated in their proper places, learn.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:20
verses.text: There is among the Persians in a city Ampa, near the river Tigris, a well; and near the well, at the top, has been constructed a certain reservoir, supplied with three outlets; and when one pumps from this well, and draws off some of its contents in a vessel, what is thus pumped out of the well, whatever it is at all, he pours into the reservoir hard by.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:21
verses.text: And when what is thus infused reaches the outlets, and when what is taken up (out of each outlet) in a single vessel is examined, a separation is observed to have taken place.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:22
verses.text: And in the first of the outlets is exhibited a concretion of salt, and in the second of asphalt, and in the third of oil; and the oil is black, just as, he says, Herodotus also narrates, and it yields a heavy smell, and the Persians call this "rhadinace".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 16:23
verses.text: The similitude of the well is, say the Sethians, more sufficient for the demonstration of their proposition than all the statements that have been previously made.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 17

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 17:1
verses.text: The Sethian Doctrines to Be Learned from the "Paraphrase of Seth".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 17:2
verses.text: The opinion of the Sethians appears to us to have been sufficiently elucidated.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 17:3
verses.text: If, however, any one is desirous of learning the entire doctrine according to them, let him read a book inscribed Paraphrase of Seth; for all their secret tenets he will find deposited there.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 17:4
verses.text: But since we have explained the opinions entertained by the Sethians, let us see also what are the doctrines advanced by Justinus.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 18

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 18:1
verses.text: The System of Justinus Antiscriptural and Essentially Pagan.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 18:2
verses.text: Justinus was entirely opposed to the teaching of the holy Scriptures, and moreover to the written or oral teaching of the blessed evangelists, according as the Logos was accustomed to instruct His disciples, saying, "Go not into the way of the Gentiles;" and this signifies that they should not attend to the futile doctrine of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 18:3
verses.text: This (heretic) endeavours to lead on his hearers into an acknowledgment of prodigies detailed by the Gentiles, and of doctrines inculcated by them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 18:4
verses.text: And he narrates, word for word, legendary accounts prevalent among the Greeks, and does not previously teach or deliver his perfect mystery, unless he has bound his dupe by an oath.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 18:5
verses.text: Then he brings forward (these) fables for the purpose of persuasion, in order that they who are conversant with the incalculable trifling of these books may have some consolation in the details of these legends.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 18:6
verses.text: Thus it happens as when in like manner one making a long journey deems it expedient, on having fallen in with an inn, to take repose.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 18:7
verses.text: And so it is that, when once more they are induced to turn towards studying the diffuse doctrine of these lectures, they may not abhor them while they, undergoing instruction unnecessarily prolix, rush stupified into the transgression devised by (Justinus); and previously he binds his followers with horrible oaths, neither to publish nor abjure these doctrines, and forces upon them an acknowledgment (of their truth).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 18:8
verses.text: And in this manner he delivers the mysteries impiously discovered by himself, partly, according to the statements previously made, availing himself of the Hellenic legends, and partly of those pretended books which, to some extent, bear a resemblance to the foresaid heresies.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 18:9
verses.text: For all, forced together by one spirit, are drawn into one profound abyss of pollution, inculcating the same tenets, and detailing the same legends, each after a different method.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 18:10
verses.text: All those, however, style themselves Gnostics in this peculiar sense, that they alone themselves have imbibed the marvellous knowledge of the Perfect and Good (Being).

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 19

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 19:1
verses.text: The Justinian Heresy Unfolded in the "Book of Baruch".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 19:2
verses.text: But swear, says Justinus, if you wish to know "what eye hath not seen, and ear hath not heard, and the things which have not entered into the heart;" that is, if you wish to know Him who is good above all, Him who is more exalted, (swear) that you will preserve the secrets (of the Justinian) discipline, as intended to be kept silent.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 19:3
verses.text: For also our Father, on beholding the Good One, and on being initiated with Him, preserved the mysteries respecting which silence is enjoined, and sware, as it has been written, "The Lord sware, and will not repent".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 19:4
verses.text: Having, then, in this way set the seal to these tenets, he seeks to inveigle (his followers) with more legends, (which are detailed) through a greater number of books; and so he conducts (his readers) to the Good One, consummating the initiated (by admitting them into) the unspeakable Mysteries.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 19:5
verses.text: In order, however, that we may not wade through more of their volumes, we shall illustrate the ineffable Mysteries (of Justinus) from one book of his, inasmuch as, according to his supposition, it is (a work) of high repute.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 19:6
verses.text: Now this volume is inscribed Baruch; and one fabulous account out of many which is explained by (Justinus) in this (volume), we shall point out, inasmuch as it is to be found in Herodotus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 19:7
verses.text: But after imparting a different shape to this (account), he explains it to his pupils as if it were something novel, being under the impression that the entire arrangement of his doctrine (springs) out of it.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 20

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 20:1
verses.text: The Cosmogony of Justinus an Allegorical Explanation of Herodotus' Legend of Hercules.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 20:2
verses.text: Herodotus, then, asserts that Hercules, when driving the oxen of Geryon from Erytheia, came into Scythia, and that, being wearied with travelling, he retired into some desert spot and slept for a short time.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 20:3
verses.text: But while he slumbered his horse disappeared, seated on which he had performed his lengthened journey.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 20:4
verses.text: On being aroused from repose, he, however, instituted a diligent search through the desert, endeavouring to discover his horse.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 20:5
verses.text: And though he is unsuccessful in his search after the horse, he yet finds in the desert a certain damsel, half of whose form was that of woman, and proceeded to question her if she had seen the horse anywhere.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 20:6
verses.text: The girl, however, replies that she had seen (the animal), but that she would not show him unless Hercules previously would come along with her for the purpose of sexual intercourse.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 20:7
verses.text: Now Herodotus informs us that her upper parts as far as the groin were those of a virgin, but that everything below the body after the groin presented some horrible appearance of a snake.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 20:8
verses.text: In anxiety, however, for the discovery of his horse, Hercules complies with the monster's request; for he knew her (carnally), and made her pregnant.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 20:9
verses.text: And he foretold, after coition, that she had by him in her womb three children at the same time, who were destined to become illustrious.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 20:10
verses.text: And he ordered that she, on bringing forth, should impose on the children as soon as born the following names: Agathyrsus, Gelonus, and Scytha.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 20:11
verses.text: And as the reward of this (favour) receiving his horse from the beast-like damsel, he went on his way, taking with him the cattle also.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 20:12
verses.text: But after these (details), Herodotus has a protracted account; adieu, however, to it for the present.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 20:13
verses.text: But what the opinions are of Justinus, who transfers this legend into (his account of) the generation of the universe, we shall explain.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:1
verses.text: Justinus' Triad of Principles; His Angelography Founded on This Triad; His Explanation of the Birth, Life, and Death of Our Lord.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:2
verses.text: This (heresiarch) makes the following statement.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:3
verses.text: There are three unbegotten principles of the universe, two male (and) one female.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:4
verses.text: Of the male (principles), however, a certain one, is denominated good, and it alone is called after this manner, and possesses a power of prescience concerning the universe.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:5
verses.text: But the other is father of all begotten things, devoid of prescience, and invisible.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:6
verses.text: And the female (principle) is devoid of prescience, passionate, two-minded, two-bodied, in every respect answering (the description of) the girl in the legend of Herodotus, as far as the groin a virgin, and (in) the parts below (resembling) a snake, as Justinus says.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:7
verses.text: But this girl is styled Edem and Israel.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:8
verses.text: And these principles of the universe are, he says, roots and fountains from which existing things have been produced, but that there was not anything else.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:9
verses.text: The Father, then, who is devoid of prescience, beholding that half-woman Edem, passed into a concupiscent desire for her.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:10
verses.text: But this Father, he says, is called Elohim.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:11
verses.text: Not less did Edem also long for Elohim, and the mutual passion brought them together into the one nuptial couch of love.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:12
verses.text: And from such an intercourse the Father generates out of Edem unto himself twelve angels.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:13
verses.text: And the names of the angels begotten by the Father are these: Michaël, Amen, Baruch, Gabriel, Esaddaeus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:14
verses.text: …And of the maternal angels which Edem brought forth, the names in like manner have been subjoined, and they are as follows: Babel, Achamoth, Naas, Bel, Belias, Satan, Saël, Adonaeus, Leviathan, Pharao, Carcamenos, (and) Lathen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:15
verses.text: Of these twenty-four angels the paternal ones are associated with the Father, and do all things according to His will; and the maternal (angels are associated with) Edem the Mother.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:16
verses.text: And the multitude of all these angels together is Paradise, he says, concerning which Moses speaks: "God planted a garden in Eden towards the east," that is, towards the face of Edem, that Edem might behold the garden—that is, the angels—continually.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:17
verses.text: Allegorically the angels are styled trees of this garden, and the tree of life is the third of the paternal angels—Baruch.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:18
verses.text: And the tree of the knowledge of good and evil is the third of the maternal angels—Naas.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:19
verses.text: For so, says (Justinus), one ought to interpret the words of Moses, observing, "Moses said these things disguisedly, from the fact that all do not attain the truth".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:20
verses.text: And, he says, Paradise being formed from the conjugal joy of Elohim and Edem, the angels of Elohim receiving from the most beauteous earth, that is, not from the portion of Edem resembling a monster, but from the parts above the groin of human shape, and gentle—in aspect,—make man out of the earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:21
verses.text: But out of the parts resembling a monster are produced wild beasts, and the rest of the animal creation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:22
verses.text: They made man, therefore, as a symbol of the unity and love (subsisting) between them; and they depute their own powers unto him, Edem the soul, but Elohim the spirit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:23
verses.text: And the man Adam is produced as some actual seal and memento of love, and as an everlasting emblem of the marriage of Edem and Elohim.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:24
verses.text: And in like manner also Eve was produced, he says, as Moses has described, an image and emblem (as well as) a seal, to be preserved for ever, of Edem.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:25
verses.text: And in like manner also a soul was deposited in Eve,—an image—from Edem, but a spirit from Elohim.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:26
verses.text: And there were given to them commandments, "Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth," that is, Edem; for so he wishes that it had been written.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:27
verses.text: For the entire of the power belonging unto herself, Edem conferred upon Elohim as a sort of nuptial dowry.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:28
verses.text: Whence, he says, from imitation of that primary marriage up to this day, women bring a dowry to their husbands, complying with a certain divine and paternal law that came into existence on the part of Edem towards Elohim.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:29
verses.text: And when all things were created as has been described by Moses—both heaven and earth, and the things therein—the twelve angels of the Mother were divided into four principles, and each fourth part of them is called a river—Phison, and Gehon, and Tigris, and Euphrates, as, he says, Moses states.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:30
verses.text: These twelve angels, being mutually connected, go about into four parts, and manage the world, holding from Edem a sort of viceregal authority over the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:31
verses.text: But they do not always continue in the same places, but move around as if in a circular dance, changing place after place, and at set times and intervals retiring to the localities subject to themselves.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:32
verses.text: And when Phison holds sway over places, famine, distress, and affliction prevail in that part of the earth, for the battalion of these angels is niggardly.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:33
verses.text: In like manner also there belong to each part of the four, according to the power and nature of each, evil times and hosts of diseases.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:34
verses.text: And continually, according to the dominion of each fourth part, this stream of evil, just (like a current) of rivers, careers, according to the will of Edem, uninterruptedly around the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:35
verses.text: And from some cause of this description has arisen the necessity of evil.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:36
verses.text: When Elohim had prepared and created the world as a result from joint pleasure, He wished to ascend up to the elevated parts of heaven, and to see that not anything of what pertained to the creation laboured under deficiency.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:37
verses.text: And He took His Own angels with Him, for His nature was to mount aloft, leaving Edem below: for inasmuch as she was earth, she was not disposed to follow upward her spouse.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:38
verses.text: Elohim, then, coming to the highest part of heaven above, and beholding a light superior to that which He Himself had created, exclaimed, "Open me the gates, that entering in I may acknowledge the Lord; for I considered Myself to be Lord".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:39
verses.text: A voice was returned to Him from the light, saying, "This is the gate of the Lord: through this the righteous enter in".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:40
verses.text: And immediately the gate was opened, and the Father, without the angels, entered, (advancing) towards the Good One, and beheld "what eye hath not seen, and ear hath not heard, and what hath not entered into the heart of man to (conceive)".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:41
verses.text: Then the Good One says to him, "Sit thou on my right hand".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:42
verses.text: And the Father says to the Good One, "Permit me, Lord, to overturn the world which I have made, for my spirit is bound to men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:43
verses.text: And I wish to receive it back (from them".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:44
