verses.text: Then the Good One replies to him, "No evil canst thou do while thou art with me, for both thou and Edem made the world as a result of conjugal joy.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:45
verses.text: Permit Edem, then, to hold possession of the world as long as she wishes; but do you remain with me".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:46
verses.text: Then Edem, knowing that she had been deserted by Elohim, was seized with grief, and placed beside herself her own angels.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:47
verses.text: And she adorned herself after a comely fashion, if by any means Elohim, passing into concupiscent desire, might descend (from heaven) to her.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:48
verses.text: When, however, Elohim, overpowered by the Good One, no longer descended to Edem, Edem commanded Babel, which is Venus, to cause adulteries and dissolutions of marriages among men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:49
verses.text: (And she adopted this expedient) in order that, as she had been divorced from Elohim, so also the spirit of Elohim, which is in men, being wrong with sorrow, might be punished by such separations, and might undergo precisely the sufferings which (were being endured by) the deserted Edem.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:50
verses.text: And Edem gives great power to her third angel, Naas, that by every species of punishment she might chasten the spirit of Elohim which is in men, in order that Elohim, through the spirit, might be punished for having deserted his spouse, in violation of the agreements entered into between them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:51
verses.text: Elohim the father, seeing these things, sends forth Baruch, the third angel among his own, to succour the spirit that is in all men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:52
verses.text: Baruch then coming, stood in the midst of the angels of Edem, that is, in the midst of paradise—for paradise is the angels, in the midst of whom he stood,—and issued to the man the following injunction: "Of every tree that is in paradise thou mayest freely eat, but thou mayest not eat of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil," which is Naas.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:53
verses.text: Now the meaning is, that he should obey the rest of the eleven angels of Edem, for the eleven possess passions, but are not guilty of transgression.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:54
verses.text: Naas, however, has committed sin, for he went in unto Eve, deceiving her, and debauched her; and (such an act as) this is a violation of law.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:55
verses.text: He, however, likewise went in unto Adam, and had unnatural intercourse with him; and this is itself also a piece of turpitude, whence have arisen adultery and sodomy.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:56
verses.text: Henceforward vice and virtue were prevalent among men, arising from a single source—that of the Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:57
verses.text: For the Father having ascended to the Good One, points out from time to time the way to those desirous of ascending (to him likewise).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:58
verses.text: After having, however, departed from Edem, he caused an originating principle of evil for the spirit of the Father that is in men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:59
verses.text: Baruch therefore was despatched to Moses, and through him spoke to the children of Israel, that they might be converted unto the Good One.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:60
verses.text: But the third angel (Naas), by the soul which came from Edem upon Moses, as also upon all men, obscured the precepts of Baruch, and caused his own peculiar injunctions to be hearkened unto.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:61
verses.text: For this reason the soul is arrayed against the spirit, and the spirit against the soul.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:62
verses.text: For the soul is Edem, but the spirit Elohim, and each of these exists in all men, both females and males.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:63
verses.text: Again, after these (occurrences), Baruch was sent to the Prophets, that through the Prophets the spirit that dwelleth in men might hear (words of warning), and might avoid Edem and the wicked fiction, just as the Father had fled from Elohim.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:64
verses.text: In like manner also—by the prophets—Naas, by a similar device, through the soul that dwells in man, along with the spirit of the Father, enticed away the prophets, and all (of them) were allured after him, and did not follow the words of Baruch, which Elohim enjoined.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:65
verses.text: Ultimately Elohim selected Hercules, an uncircumcised prophet, and sent him to quell the twelve angels of Edem, and release the Father from the twelve angels, those wicked ones of the creation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:66
verses.text: These are the twelve conflicts of Hercules which Hercules underwent, in order, from first to last, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:67
verses.text: , Lion, and Hydra, and Boar, and the others successively.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:68
verses.text: For they say that these are the names (of them) among the Gentiles, and they have been derived with altered denominations from the energy of the maternal angels.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:69
verses.text: When he seemed to have vanquished his antagonists, Omphale—now she is Babel or Venus—clings to him and entices away Hercules, and divests him of his power, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:70
verses.text: , the commands of Baruch which Elohim issued.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:71
verses.text: And in place (of this power, Babel) envelopes him in her own peculiar robe, that is, in the power of Edem, who is the power below; and in this way the prophecy of Hercules remained unfulfilled, and his works.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:72
verses.text: Finally, however, in the days of Herod the king, Baruch is despatched, being sent down once more by Elohim; and coming to Nazareth, he found Jesus, son of Joseph and Mary, a child of twelve years, feeding sheep.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:73
verses.text: And he announces to him all things from the beginning, whatsoever had been done by Edem and Elohim, and whatsoever would be likely to take place hereafter, and spoke the following words: "All the prophets anterior to you have been enticed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:74
verses.text: Put forth an effort, therefore, Jesus, Son of man, not to be allured, but preach this word unto men, and carry back tidings to them of things pertaining to the Father, and things pertaining to the Good One, and ascend to the Good One, and sit there with Elohim, Father of us all".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:75
verses.text: And Jesus was obedient unto the angel, saying that, "I shall do all things, Lord," and proceeded to preach.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:76
verses.text: Naas therefore wished to entice this one also.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:77
verses.text: (Jesus, however, was not disposed to listen to his overtures), for he remained faithful to Baruch.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:78
verses.text: Therefore Naas, being inflamed with anger because he was not able to seduce him, caused him to be crucified.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:79
verses.text: He, however, leaving the body of Edem on the (accursed) tree, ascended to the Good One; saying, however, to Edem, "Woman, thou retainest thy son," that is, the natural and the earthly man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:80
verses.text: But (Jesus) himself commending his spirit into the hands of the Father, ascended to the Good One.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:81
verses.text: Now the Good One is Priapus, (and) he it is who antecedently caused the production of everything that exists.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:82
verses.text: On this account he is styled Priapus, because he previously fashioned all things (according to his own design).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:83
verses.text: For this reason, he says, in every temple is placed his statue, which is revered by every creature; and (there are images of him) in the highways, carrying over his head ripened fruits, that is, the produce of the creation, of which he is the cause, having in the first instance formed, (according to His own design), the creation, when as yet it had no existence.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:84
verses.text: When, therefore, he says, you hear men asserting that the swan went in unto Leda, and begat a child from her, (learn that) the swan is Elohim, and Leda Edem.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:85
verses.text: And when people allege that an eagle went in unto Ganymede, (know that) the eagle is Naas, and Ganymede Adam.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:86
verses.text: And when they assert that gold (in a shower) went in unto Danaë and begat a child from her, (recollect that) the gold is Elohim, and Danaë is Edem.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:87
verses.text: And similarly, in the same manner adducing all accounts of this description, which correspond with (the nature of) legends, they pursue the work of instruction.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:88
verses.text: When, therefore, the prophet says, "Hearken, O heaven, and give ear, O earth; the Lord hath spoken," he means by heaven, (Justinus) says, the spirit which is in man from Elohim; and by earth, the soul which is in man along with the spirit; and by Lord, Baruch; and by Israel, Edem, for Israel as well as Edem is called the spouse of Elohim.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 21:89
verses.text: "Israel," he says, "did not know me (Elohim); for had he known me, that I am with the Good One, he would not have punished through paternal ignorance the spirit which is in men".

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 22

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 22:1
verses.text: Oath Used by the Justinian Heretics; The Book of Baruch; The Repertory of Their System.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 22:2
verses.text: Hence also, in the first book inscribed "Baruch," has been written the oath which they compel those to swear who are about to hear these mysteries, and be initiated with the Good One.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 22:3
verses.text: And this oath, (Justinus) says, our Father Elohim sware when He was beside the Good One, and having sworn He did not repent (of the oath), respecting which, he says, it has been written, "The Lord sware, and will not repent".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 22:4
verses.text: Now the oath is couched in these terms: "I swear by that Good One who is above all, to guard these mysteries, and to divulge them to no one, and not to relapse from the Good One to the creature".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 22:5
verses.text: And when he has sworn this oath, he goes on to the Good One, and beholds "whatever things eye hath not seen, and ear hath not heard, and which have not entered into the heart of man;" and he drinks from life-giving water, which is to them, as they suppose, a bath, a fountain of life-giving, bubbling water.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 22:6
verses.text: For there has been a separation made between water and water; and there is water, that below the firmament of the wicked creation, in which earthly and animal men are washed; and there is life-giving water, (that) above the firmament, of the Good One, in which spiritual (and) living men are washed; and in this Elohim washed Himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 22:7
verses.text: and having washed did not repent.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 22:8
verses.text: And when, he says, the prophet affirms, "Take unto yourself a wife of whoredom, since the earth has abandoned itself to fornication, (departing) from (following) after the Lord;" that is, Edem (departs) from Elohim.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 22:9
verses.text: (Now) in these words, he says, the prophet clearly declares the entire mystery, and is not hearkened unto by reason of the wicked machinations of Naas.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 22:10
verses.text: According to that same manner, they deliver other prophetical passages in a similar spirit of interpretation throughout numerous books.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 22:11
verses.text: The volume, however, inscribed "Baruch," is pre-eminently to them the one in which the reader will ascertain the entire explanation of their legendary system (to be contained).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 22:12
verses.text: Beloved, though I have encountered many heresies, yet with no wicked (heresiarch) worse than this (Justinus) has it been my lot to meet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 22:13
verses.text: But, in truth, (the followers of Justinus) ought to imitate the example of his Hercules, and to cleanse, as the saying is, the cattle-shed of Augias, or rather I should say, a ditch, into which, as soon as the adherents of this (heresiarch) have fallen, they can never be cleansed; nay, they will not be able even to raise their heads.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 23

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 23:1
verses.text: Subsequent Heresies Deducible from the System of Justinus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 23:2
verses.text: Since, then, we have explained the attempts (at a system) of the pseudo-gnostic Justinus, it appears likewise expedient in the following books to elucidate the opinions put forward in heresies following (in the way of consequence upon the doctrines of Justinus), and to leave not a single one of these (speculators) unrefuted.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 23:3
verses.text: Our refutation will be accomplished by adducing the assertions made by them; such (at least of their statements) as are sufficient for making a public example (of these heretics).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 23:4
verses.text: (And we shall attain our purpose), even though there should only be condemned the secret and ineffable (mysteries) practised amongst them, into which, silly mortals that they are, scarcely (even) with considerable labour are they initiated.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Refutation of All Heresies IV 23:5
verses.text: Let us then see what also Simon affirms.
